PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. there is a lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on Plant Variety Rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks;
5. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax payer, and
6. evidence suggests that Plant Varietal Rights legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament ensure:
(i) that information be made freely available to allow full and informed public discussion of the issues involved,
(ii) that the Government undertake to carry out an analysis of the costs and benefits involved to the various sectors of Agriculture and the Nation as a whole.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

—Has the attention of the Leader of the Government in the Senate been invited to a statement in the Sydney Press today in which the honourable member for Phillip made a strong personal attack on the senators who crossed the floor and voted against the Government on the Freedom of Information Bill? He described them as schoolgirls and spoilt senators who were sulking because they did not get their own way. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know one thing about sectionalism: The phenomenon that, whilst members of the Government parties cross the floor from time to time on matters that they feel are of importance, I have yet to see in all my time in politics a member of the Australian Labor Party ever prove a question of conscience by crossing the floor. I am asked how I feel. I believe that what is revealed from day to day is that within the Government parties there is a freedom of conscience--
—Good.

—And also a very significant freedom of responsibility. Senator Button interjects and says 'good'. It is good, apparently, for members of the Government parties but bad for the members of the party that Senator Button leads in this chamber.

ANSWER.PARA: I did not see the statement in the newspaper by a member of another place. In my party he is freely entitled to express his views. That is not a freedom that those in the Australian Labor Party are allowed to exercise.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Australian Labor Party get very tender indeed when the vast dichotomy between the two parties in terms of principle and freedom is demonstrated. I have not seen the statement in the Press. Members of the Government parties in the normal course of their duties understand their own collective responsibilities and support the policies of the Government as they come through. On the few occasions that they cross the floor the Press, for some extraordinary reason, sees this as a division in the parties. On the contrary, it shows freedom which, used sparingly-because there is a heavy responsibility upon the member-is a very valuable asset within the parties. I commend the principle to the Australian Labor Party without, however, much hope that it will be taken up.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy to the report of statements by Dr Edward Lumsdaine, Director of the Energy, Environment and Resource Centre at the University of Tennessee, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . that the United States Government solar energy program has been 'an absolute waste of money' and believes the prospects of the solar industry are a far cry from the rosy view put across to the public by its advocates.
The report goes on to claim:
The number of US solar manufacturers has reduced from about 365 to 270 over 12 months.
Nine out of the top 10 solar collector manufacturers in the US made a loss last year.
Exxon Corp last month sold its solar collector subsidiary, Daystar, for $US2.2 million . . .
Having spent $10m on upgrading it. Can the Minister comment on the statements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the statement of the particular gentleman from Tennessee, nor would I take such a pessimistic view of the future of solar energy. What is true is that the present state of the art, the present knowledge of technology, is such that the use of solar energy is very limited or restricted. Often the production of solar arrays uses as much, or more, energy as in a lifetime they may save. That is not to be taken at this stage as a criticism. Above everything, we want to find renewable energy sources that will be able to replace the non-renewables-the oils, the coals and the shales. The present development of solar arrays means that very large areas have to be used to produce relatively small agglomerations or accumulations of heat. Much more work has to be done in the photovoltaic cell area and much more work has to be done in collector systems to focus a greater intensity of heat in a particular concentration.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, there is a significant and growing use of solar energy. My Government and I have anticipated that in some 20 years' time solar energy could be providing about 8 per cent of Australia's energy needs. What is needed-what is being done-is to concentrate research on this matter. Recently in Western Australia I was privileged to see quite a lot of very useful research going on. It is also going on in other States. I would like to see the research intensified. We are working with the Japanese towards the possibility of establishing, in the Northern Territory, a pilot plant that will provide a significant collector system. I hope that that will be done. I do not want to knock solar energy; I do not want to be over-pessimistic. On the other hand, realism suggests that at this stage of development much more concentration of research and technology is required, and that is what we are aiming to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, concerns East Timor. Is it a fact that the Republic of Indonesia had, and has, no ethnic, historic or moral justification whatsoever for its invasion and subsequent occupation of East Timor? Has Indonesia carried out a deliberate and protracted policy of genocide against the East Timorese people? Will the Australian Government now support, with vigour and expedition, the approach from the Prime Minister of Portugal, Mr Balsemao, to the United Nations Secretary-General, Dr Waldheim, for self-determination in East Timor, whose people helped Australian servicemen so much at so much self-sacrifice during World War II? If the Government will not give this immediate support, why will not it do so?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government regrets the circumstances under which Indonesia took control of East Timor. However, it believes that the best interests of the people of Timor are now served by positive encouragement of the Indonesian Government in its efforts to improve the living conditions of the population. I am aware of Press reports that the Portuguese Foreign Minister asked the United Nations Secretary-General, Dr Waldheim, to set up a special committee on East Timor. It is noted that Dr Waldheim is reported to have indicated that no decision could be taken on the idea without consulting all interested parties, including Indonesia. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Government hope that Dr Waldheim's mission will lead to a satisfactory solution of this long-standing problem. If there is any further information on this matter that I am able to provide, I will see that Senator Mason is advised of it.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister please answer my direct question? Will the Government support the effort?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not in a position to answer that question on behalf of the Foreign Minister. I will see that it is referred to him and have an early response for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELEPHONE CALLS BETWEEN MELBOURNE AND HOBART

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and refers to an advertisement that appeared in several newspapers last week headed 'Long distance for less'. The advertisement suggests that there will be a 20 to 25 per cent reduction in long distance telephone call rates over certain distances. Is the Minister aware that this large reduction in rates will apply between Melbourne and Sydney, Sydney and Brisbane, and Melbourne and Adelaide, amongst other places, but not between Melbourne and Hobart? In other words, the reduction will apply between all adjacent capital cities in the east of Australia, except between Melbourne and Hobart. Obviously I ask: Will the Government examine or ask Telecom Australia to examine the situation to see whether the reduction can apply between Melbourne and Hobart?

—I wish that I had seen the advertisement to which the honourable senator refers. I have now seen it held up by the honourable senator, but I have not had a chance to read it, nor can I from this distance. The matter was raised with me over the weekend by someone else. I understand that Senator Townley, in raising this question, welcomes the reduced rates offered and is acknowledging that if that is so it is an advance for many people using the services of Telecom. However the point of his question is why these reduced rates do not cross that body of water separating Tasmania from the rest of Australia. The honourable senator asked: Can I undertake to seek from my colleague an assurance that this matter will be referred to Telecom for its consideration? Of course I shall accede to that request, knowing, as all honourable senators do, the interest that Senator Townley has in the affairs of Tasmania and his concern that the citizens of his State should receive a fair go at all times.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery of a former highly respected member of this place in the person of Mr George Hannan. To him and to Mrs Hannan, we tender a very warm welcome.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that at the Premiers Conference of last week there was never any agreement on the part of any State Premier with the Federal Government's so-called final offer? Was part of the Commonwealth's argument to the Premiers that any savings to the Federal Treasury as a result of the squeeze on the States must be returned to the taxpayers of Australia by way of income tax cuts? Does the Minister agree with the statement by the Premier of New South Wales that the Federal Government therefore has the capacity to offer income tax cuts of 10 per cent from 1 July next, representing an amount of about $8 a week for the average taxpayer? Finally, with substantial increases occurring in hospital charges and reduced services being provided, at both Federal and State levels, directly as a result of the Government's decisions of the last fortnight, is there any truth in the report that the Government is considering imposing heavy increases in excise charges on wage and salary earners in the next Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —All honourable senators will know that it is the normal routine-almost a ritual-following a Premiers Conference that the Premiers, even though they may feel they have got a fair deal, never express that feeling and always express dissatisfaction. Premiers Conference after Premiers Conference the Premiers do not indicate agreement, and they did not indicate agreement following their last meeting. I am bound to say to the honourable senator that a number of Premiers indicated that in the past the formula had been considerably generous and they expected any formula for the future would be less generous. Senator McClelland well knows that the original offer of the Government was 8 per cent, modified to 8.4 per cent and finally concluded at 9 per cent. It was the Commonwealth's offer at each stage that the Premiers declined, but that is not unusual. It was not indicated at the Premiers Conference that the primary purpose of any program, whether it be the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee program, the health program or tax sharing, would be to give tax benefits. At all points it was stressed that it was necessary to get the economy into a deflationary state that would enable us to expand, to do more and to provide more jobs and more industries for Australia; that that was the primary goal. Indeed, the evidence indicates that that is working, and that is acknowledged overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, it is also the keen desire of the Government that it should, where it can, provide tax cuts. The Commonwealth has set such an example in the past. I have seen something of the comment of Mr Wran. I am interested to learn that he accepts savings should be made through payments to the States and suggests that those savings might be directed towards tax cuts, but I cannot comment on whether his formula of 10 per cent is over-generous or not. I note that the State Premiers have a capacity to give advice on Commonwealth budgetary matters very frequently. The fact is that a new hospital and health scheme has been introduced throughout Australia. I think it is important for the Senate to realise that at least four Premiers have expressed the view that they accept the health scheme in principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which four?

—I will be happy to get the statements and let the Senate know. The fact is that that has been said. I think one of the Deputy Premiers expressed that view forcibly on AM this morning. It is a fact that there will be increases in hospital charges in order to meet the increased costs of health. As to Senator McClelland's last question, he knows better than I that no government will make any kind of statement about what is going to happen in the Budget, whether by way of revenue or expenditure. Of course, at this moment a keen campaign regarding excise is running in the Press and elsewhere in the media. I ask everybody to abate their thirst and their curiosity for the next few months when the secrets of all hearts will be disclosed.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, refers to the large protest from the community in relation to Telecom Australia attempting to charge consumers for non-connection to international subscriber dialling services and for non-listing of subscribers in telephone books. I ask: Are we perhaps witnessing a new realism in some statutory authorities and that they are at last charging for non-services to the public? Is there any possibility of this move spreading to the Public Service at large?

—I am interested to hear Senator MacGibbon say that there has been a large protest. I am not aware of any large protest on this matter. As one of those who chooses to have my telephone number non-listed I certainly have not protested. I would like to say that I and many other Australians regard the capacity not to be listed in telephone directories as a very distinct service and one which we would not want to give up easily. There are various reasons why we do not wish to be listed, not least of all because there have been some rather unpleasant telephone calls over a number of years directed, while I have been in Canberra, not at me but at my family.
—Why don't you--

—I appreciate Senator McLaren's attempt to tell me how to do my job but I am listed under numerous telephone numbers on which people can and do contact me. Senator MacGibbon's question is really related to whether people should pay for the privilege of not having their service listed. He will be aware, of course, that one of the main calls upon directory assistance is from people pursuing telephone numbers which they cannot find in the directory and which prove to be those unlisted numbers. They take longer to deal with because people actually require a considerable amount of explanation as to why those numbers cannot be released. It has turned out that there is quite a cost to Telecom in maintaining that service-directory assistance-and explaining why various subscribers have chosen not to have their numbers listed. Having said all that, I am aware of the more frivolous or humourous part of Senator MacGibbon's question. I think I might refer that to my colleague for his enjoyment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: SURPLUS AIRCRAFT

Was an offer of $1m an aeroplane made by Captain Ellis and Mr Woods from Melbourne on behalf of the Mexican Government and the United Nations? Was a tender for a lesser amount finally accepted from the American company Parmax Incorporated which turned out to be a company with a contract for cleaning airports in America? —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of reports this week that Prince Norodom Sihanouk has now successfully welded together a 'third group' with the potential to regain leadership in Kampuchea and achieve a stable, moderate and unifying government for Cambodia? What is the Australian Government's assessment of this significant development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer that matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for his assessment of the position as it stands at the moment.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In June 1978 the private health funds in Australia owed the Government millions of dollars. This was because Medibank had paid claims which should rightfully have been paid by the private funds. It occurred during the period of the restructuring of the health scheme so that beneficiaries would not be disadvantaged. The health funds said at the time that they would not pay back the money. When I asked in June 1978 what action the Minister proposed I was advised that the money owed would be vigorously pursued. When I asked about the matter again in November 1978 the Minister advised that there was doubt about the legality of pursuing the claims and that the Government would not insist on repayment. In view of the Government's deep concern to cut government costs and, presumably, its anxiety to collect all money owing to it, will the Minister advise what possible legalities prevent it from collecting these millions of dollars from the private health funds?

—I recall some concern a couple of years ago over the matter to which the honourable senator referred. I also recall that it was the time when it was necessary for us to vote very large amounts of money to Medibank to get it out of considerable financial difficulties-I think to the tune of $10m or $20m at that stage. The question which the honourable senator asked concerns some doubts about the legality of certain proposed courses of action. I am not certain that I can answer the question properly within the Standing Orders in any event. It will require information from my colleague the Minister for Health. I will undertake to refer that matter to him for the honourable senator.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I understand that the Minister travelled to Darwin last weekend and discussed matters relating to the Koongarra uranium deposit and also Northern Territory land rights. As there has been considerable publicity in regard to the matter, can the Minister advise on the talks and what action is likely to emanate from his visit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some time it had been arranged that I should return to Darwin for a meeting on 11 May. This followed an earlier meeting held on 19 March between representatives of the Northern Territory Government, the Commonwealth Government and the three land councils in the Northern Territory. At that first meeting we explored a number of issues concerning matters relating to the administration of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and we made considerable progress on a number of agreed positions which might form the basis for some amendments.

ANSWER.PARA: The meeting on 11 May, yesterday, was a long planned follow-up meeting. I understand that discussion is going on today to try to reach some further agreed positions which might be acceptable to the land councils, to the Northern Territory Government and to the Commonwealth Government. I think all honourable senators would realise that it is in everyone's interest to have an Aboriginal land rights Act in operation in the Northern Territory which, in addition to looking after the legitimate interests of Aboriginal people, can properly advance the cause of racial harmony and community development on all sides. If, in fact, we reach an agreed position in which the land councils themselves are active participants-that is something which most people would, of course, commend-the positions would have to be taken back to the land councils and I would have to go back to the Commonwealth Government to have the proposals examined further.

Let me now answer the second part of the honourable senator's question. While I was in Darwin I took the opportunity to talk to some of those who are concerned with the Koongarra negotiations and to reinforce the point that I made in this place last week that the whole of the Kakadu National Park is Aboriginal land; that for any mining to take place on that land requires the consent provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act to be followed completely; and that there is no intention that those consent provisions should be set aside.

I was aware, as I think most of those to whom I spoke were aware, of an excision from the Kakadu National Park made, I think, in 1977. That excision was made to provide for the possibility of later mining on the Koongarra project. Of course, that excision would have effect only if eventual consent were given by the traditional owners. Any proposal for an altered excision area would be dealt with on exactly the same basis-it would not have effect of any kind unless consent to mining were given by the traditional owners. I found the discussions, which are continuing, very fruitful and productive. I undertake to keep the honourable senator advised of any further progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In keeping with the Federal Government's policy of appointing women to public boards and committees, could the Minister tell me how many women are members of the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee? If the answer is none, when will a woman be appointed?

—It is some time since I have examined the actual list of members of the Committee to which the honourable senator refers. I do not recall that any of its members were women. However, I cannot tell her whether that is the current situation. I undertake to find out the information from my colleague and to make known to him the suggestion which the honourable senator has made.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RIVER MURRAY: SOUTH AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT STUDY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he has seen reports that the South Australian Government has engaged a consulting team on a study into the future of irrigation and related industries along the River Murray? As there has been grave concern-I emphasise the phrase 'grave concern'-over the recent silting of the River Murray mouth, and current and continuing concern over water quality, will the Federal Government give financial assistance for this study by the South Australian Government, as has been done in the past in the reverse situation of flood mitigation in some of the other States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator may be referring to the Riverland irrigation study. If so, I have been informed by my Department that the South Australian Government has made such a study. It would appear that the study comes within the guidelines related to assistance to the States under the National Water Resources Program. However, the availability of funds for the study would depend upon the priority accorded the study by the South Australian Government, relative to other projects.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been acutely aware of the recent silting of the mouth of the River Murray. The river has a bad habit of doing this but, happily, most times it reverts to good behaviour. I am more than acutely aware of the need for quality of water, not only in terms of salinity but also generally in regard to agricultural irrigation and town water supplies. Indeed, recently I learnt a new word, 'turbidity', to describe that nasty, brown colour that Adelaide's water tends to get.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been using it for ages to describe your speeches.

—We on the government side continue to learn. That gives us a considerable advantage. Senator Young will know that a considerable sum of money, about $60m, has been put aside over a period to get filtration and better quality water for Adelaide. I hope improvement will continue. Of course, I am very keen to complete the River Murray Agreement because that relates to both quality and quantity. I am keen to get going further developments in the Maunsell study. I am very keen indeed to reduce salinity because I know of its impact. If the Commonwealth Government can do more, it will certainly do it. It will look at any project to see whether it can come under the National Water Resources Program. If the South Australian Government then gives it the appropriate priority, it will get favourable consideration.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, refers to the present health arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and the general criticism of the Government's policy. The Minister, despite what he said this afternoon in the Senate, may know that yesterday the South Australian Minister of Health asked for support from South Australian senators to have a review made of the present health proposals. Can the Minister tell the Senate whether the Government intends to review or renegotiate any of those proposals, or does it wish the matter to be resolved in the Senate during debate on the forthcoming legislation?

—I am aware that the Minister for Health in another place had very lengthy discussions with the State Health Ministers last week and that there was a valuable exchange of viewpoints. Arising out of that, my understanding is that the Commonwealth intends to pursue the policies that it has laid down. Queensland has raised some questions which may have to come under special review because Queensland for many years has had a very special problem of free hospitals. Otherwise, the Government intends to introduce the legislation within the next week or two and there will be a debate here. As I understand it, and I am subject to correction, the Minister of Health in South Australia has welcomed the scheme in principle on a number of occasions. If there is a suggestion for a review of the proposals, it is probably a suggestion for a review as to the quantum of money rather than a challenge to the principles themselves. If any inquiry of mine shows that what I have said is not accurate, I will give the honourable senator further information.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES ELECTION FUNDING LEGISLATION

—I am leaving that for the Minister to determine. I have indicated the areas to which, under Standing Orders, he need not respond.

—I have had only a cursory look at the Bill to which Senator Lewis has referred. I am not in a position to answer any of the questions he asks-even if they were within the Standing Orders. I will look at the detail of the question and see whether there are any aspects of it to which I may properly reply.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Walsh proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Commonwealth Government to initiate moves for a constitutional guarantee of a one-vote-one-value principle, particularly in view of the proposed new electoral redistribution in Western Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1977 we have seen a sustained attack on democracy in Western Australia engineered by the State Government and Liberal Party and in particular by the Premier, Charles Court. In 1977 a Liberal Party operation of intimidation and trickery prevented large numbers of Aborigines in the Kimberley from recording their votes as a result of which that election was ultimately declared void and a by-election was held. In 1979 there was an unsuccessful attempt to change the Electoral Act in order to place impediments in the way of enrolment. That attempt failed. Unfortunately the next year a similar attempt succeeded and those impediments which do not exist and never have existed in any State or Commonwealth legislation have been placed in the way of enrolment in Western Australia and I regret to say they have been quite successful.

SPEECH.PARA: A few weeks ago some 30,000 fewer electors-that is almost 5 per cent of the State's voting population-were enrolled on the State roll compared with the number on the Commonwealth roll. This campaign has been superimposed on a long and dishonourable tradition of manipulating electoral laws to entrench governments which do not have majority support. That dishonourable tradition, of course, is not unique to Western Australia, nor has it been unique to the Liberal Party or even to the Liberal and Country parties in the past. I regret, but I acknowledge, that Labor governments, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland, in past times-now they are fairly distant past times-have been guilty of the same type, but not to the same degree, of electoral manipulation as has been practised and continues to be practised by conservative governments and as is practised now in Western Australia in particular. The fact that both political sides have done it in the past does not justify one side continuing to manipulate the electoral laws to defeat democratic processes today.

The normal method of manipulation is that malapportionment and in particular the system of malapportionment which says that there shall be a greater number of electors in urban areas per electorate than there shall be in country areas. There are some variances of that theme but basically that has been the method under which electoral malapportionment in the defeat or subversion of democracy has been practised. The normal rationale for that geographically-based malapportionment is what is euphemistically called equality of representation, by which it is argued by the people who support that system, and the conservative politicians who continue to support it, that electoral boundaries shall not be determined on the basis of population alone but there should also be a consideration of the area of the electorate, the remoteness of the electorate, and the difficulties of communication within it and between it and other electorates.

The specific form of malapportionment used in Western Australia for many decades is pursuant to the Electoral Boundaries Act under which a line is drawn arbitrarily around the city of Perth, that is the city zone; another line is drawn around the south west land division; the space between the city zone and the south west land division is the country; the eastern goldfields and the statutory seats are in the south east and in the far north of the State. The degree of malapportionment which is practised, and which has been applied for many years, is roughly that country seats shall have one-half of the number of electors-I am talking about Legislative Assembly seats-that city seats have; that goldfield electorates, of which there are now only two, shall have a number slightly lower than but comparable with country seats. Until very recently the number of electors in statutory seats in the north and the far south east had far fewer electors than even those electorates in the country zone. The boundaries within those four statutory seats were not drawn up by electoral commissioners but were laid down by legislation in the State Parliament. The boundaries of the other three zones-the country, the goldfields and the city-were determined by legislation. The boundaries of the electorates within those areas were determined by electoral commissioners.

That system and the rationale which under- pinned it-that is, the spurious concept of equality of representation incorporating population, area, remoteness, difficulties of communications and so on-are not accepted by the Labor Party and are not accepted by me. Until very recently the system was applied within Western Australia with reasonable consistency-the figures I am using are the latest figures available-thus, the largest electorate in area in the State, Murchison-Eyre, has the smallest enrolment. The second largest electorate in area, Kimberley, until quite recently had the second lowest enrolment. It now has the third lowest enrolment. Whilst there are some aberrations, as one looks at the enrolments and the electorate areas one can see that there is a very clear and negative correlation between the area of individual electorates and the number of electors on the roll. The system operated in a manner which was not inconsistent with its claimed ethical justification. The fact that it favoured the anti-Labor parties was claimed by its advocates to be coincidental-a coincidence which was fortuitous for the Liberal Party and the National Country Party but a coincidence nonetheless.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Queensland.

—The degree of malapportionment from the extremes was significantly greater than it was in Queensland. The net effect of it, insofar as it distorted the representation of the individual parties, was roughly comparable to the situation in Queensland. The new electoral districts legislation which was introduced in the Western Australian Parliament last year is a travesty, even of that doctrine of convenience. It is a corrupt perversion of democracy the like of which no previous government, not even the notorious Bjekle-Petersen Government in Queensland, has had the audacity previously to attempt. It does not even purport to have an ethical rationale. It is naked abuse of power to ensure the survival of an increasingly unpopular and alarmingly authoritarian government.

SPEECH.PARA: To give some of the details to support that charge, I refer first to the four statutory seats in the north, the far east and the south-east. I refer to the seats of Kimberley, Pilbara, Gascoyne-which is centred on Carnarvon-and Murchison-Eyre, the largest of all in area, most of which of course is uninhabited desert. The most recent enrolment figures show-for simplicity I will use round figures-that Pilbara had 15,000 electors. To the north and east of Pilbara the electorate of Kimberley had 5,700 electors, and to the south the electorate of Gascoyne had 3,700. Pilbara had for that area, indeed for the State, a number of electors well above the whole State average and almost double the average for other non-city seats. It had to the north of it an electorate with an enrolment of nearly 6,000 and to the south of it an electorate with an enrolment of 4,000. Moreover, the electorate of Kimberley, which was larger in enrolment, had an area of more than a quarter of a million square miles. The electorate of Gascoyne has an area of 64,000 square miles.

Under those circumstances and given that all of these seats adjoin, any government which was interested in applying a compound formula of the number of electors and the area of the electorate and its remoteness would have put portion of the Pilbara seat-if this were the only option-into the electorate of Gascoyne which was smaller by a large margin in area and enrolment than any of the other electorates. This was not done by the Government of Charles Court. It split in half, both demographically and geographically, the electorate of Pilbara so that the electorate of Kimberley, which is the most remote and the second largest in area-it is more than a quarter of a million square miles; almost as large as the States of New South Wales and Victoria put together-and which is in the far north of the State and inaccessible in the wet season, took one half of the electors of the Pilbara seat and the Gascoyne electorate was left untouched.

Is it not extraordinary to add more areas and electors to one seat as against another when the seat to which the numbers and the area are added has four times the area and 50 per cent more electors than the other adjoining seat? It is extraordinary until one realises why it was done. The marginal seat of Pilbara was split in half, as I have said. That half of it which had a consistent record of voting Labor-at recent elections it has had a very heavy record of voting Labor-will be put into the Labor held seat of Kimberley and the remainder, which will be called the seat of Pilbara, thereby will be made a relatively safe Liberal Party electorate. Some members of the Liberal Party have denied that this is the reason for the division. They do not go on to give an alternative explanation for the extraordinary action. Mr Withers, a member of the Legislative Council for North Province, who is no relation, to my knowledge, of Senator Withers, let the cat out of the bag when he attacked the Liberal Party for writing off the seat of Kimberley. Mr Withers said that the putting of the strongly Labor section of Pilbara into Kimberly had written off Kimberley for the Liberal Party and that Kimberley would remain a blue-ribbon Labor seat. He was thereby acknowledging, of course, that the Labor section of Pilbara was taken out of the electorate and put into Kimberley. Never mind about areas, numbers or anything at all, the electoral boundaries are being rigged so that the Charles Court Government will remain in power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another Withers interested in redistribution.

—He did not organise it, though evidently he would have organised it somewhat differently. If this proposal goes through, and it is scheduled to go through the State Parliament this week, the electorate of Kimberley, which consists of 314,000 square miles or 11 per cent of Australia, a greater area than the entire south-west land division which holds 22 country seats and which is the most distant and most inaccessible electorate, will have 12,000 electors on the roll. I know that that figure does not sound like very much in New South Wales, but it is 30 per cent larger than the average enrolment in the 22 country seats, all of which are within 300 miles of Perth and all of which could be fitted within the area of Kimberley.

SPEECH.PARA: The most remote electorate, one-third of the area of the State, has 12,000 electors. Twenty-two electorates are on the doorstep of Perth. They have 9,000 electors and a combined area of less than that of Kimberley. What has happened to the principle of equality as previously defined by the Liberal Party, this formula for electoral justice which incorporated number of electors, area, remoteness, difficulty of communication and so on? What do the small 'l' liberals, those who proclaim themselves to be the standard bearers of John Stuart Mill, think of that? How do they defend the actions of their Liberal Party? This is the same Liberal Party which is represented in this chamber and in the House of Representatives. How do they defend the actions of the Liberal Party and of the Liberal Government of Western Australia?

It is difficult to show the alternatives without a map, but if anyone cares to look at an electoral map of Western Australia and the four statutory seats which I have named, what could have been done to ensure reasonable equality both in numbers and in areas is obvious. I am talking only about the statutory seats. The southern portion, the Eyre section of Murchison-Eyre, should have been put into the seat of Yilgarn-Dundas or Kalgoorlie. The remainder of Murchison-Eyre should have been combined with the seat of Gascoyne, and Pilbara should have been split in halves. There would have been four seats with electoral enrolments varying between 5,500 and 6,000. The largest seat in area would have had the smallest number of electors and the smallest seat in area would have had the largest number of electors, in conformity with what is claimed to be the objectives of the Liberal and Country parties. The reason that was not done is that, in all probability, the Labor Party would have won three of those seats. Under the corrupt arrangement which the Court Government has engineered, the Liberal Party will most likely hold three of them.

That is not the only thing the Western Australian Government did. In the time remaining I want to touch briefly on the situation regarding this arbitrary line which is drawn around the city of Perth by the Government, not by the electoral commissioners, which separates the city from the country. In the existing country zone is the seat of Rockingham, held by Labor, with 13,000 electors. If a redistribution were held, under the pre-existing law some 3,000 or even 4,000 of those electors would have to be redistributed, which would endanger two adjoining seats currently held by the Liberal Party. The Labor Party surplus from Rockingham would endanger those seats. Solution: Put Rockingham in the city, neutralise those Labor voters and protect the two adjoining Liberal seats. Kalamunda, on the other hand, which is 10 miles closer to the GPO than Rockingham and a Liberal-held seat, remains in the country zone. Is not that amazing? A commuter suburb 10 miles closer to the GPO than Rockingham remains in the country, and Rockingham goes into the city. That is astounding until one realises the real reason it was done. These are banana republic politics which ought to be highly offensive to anyone who claims to have any affinity at all with the classical nineteenth century liberals.

Confronted with such electoral corruption-I use that word advisedly-any responsible Federal government would introduce legislation to conduct another referendum, as was done in 1974, to impose electoral democracy upon those State governments which legislate against it. This will provoke from some people a cry of States rights. States have no rights. States are a legal concept. They are inanimate institutions. States have no rights; people have rights. When the political rights of the people of Western Australia are filched, as they have been by an unscrupulous assembly of political bandits, the Commonwealth has an obligation and ought to accept the obligation to seek constitutional amendment to ensure that that practice ceases. TALK.START.PARA: —We had all hoped to hear today from Senator Walsh, who proposed this matter of public importance, some argument relating to the terms in which he proposed it, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Commonwealth Government to initiate moves for a constitutional guarantee of a one-vote-one-value principle, particularly in view of the proposed new electoral redistribution in Western Australia.

What we have heard in fact is what might be called an account of the honourable senator's domestic concerns within his own State. Only within the last minute and a half of his address did he state that in view of all this it was obvious that the Commonwealth had to do something about it.

One vote one value is a desirable principle but in this country it has always been set aside to some extent in order to meet special needs. By definition, the Senate has always done that. The value of a Tasmanian vote for that State's ten senators is much greater than that of a vote for the ten senators from the State of New South Wales from which Senator Sibraa-who I notice is in the chamber-and I come. A New South Wales voter has much less power, in terms of capacity to select a member of the Senate, than has a Tasmanian voter. If we consider the position in regard to the House of Representatives--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a different House.

—The honourable senator interjects that that is a different House. We note that since the Constitution was agreed to and Federation was achieved, Tasmania has had five guaranteed seats in that House. Those five statutory seats have always had fewer electors than those of seats representing the mainland States. Certainly more electors are required to elect a member of the House of Representatives in my State of New South Wales than is the case in Tasmania. I wish to make clear that I accept that that compact was necessary. I understand the reasons for it. I understand that although one vote one value would be desirable, that concept had to be abridged slightly in the interests of achieving the constitutional compact which led to Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: If I may return to the question of the federal system, I remind the Senate that the only powers that the Commonwealth holds are those which have been referred to it; the other plenary powers remain with the States. They include powers over the very matters to which Senator Walsh has referred. They are powers and responsibilities of the States. They are matters concerning which the States must legislate and concerning which the States must become answerable. There is a considerable movement, in the structure of Commonwealth law, away from one vote one value in respect of a number of areas of activity. Let us examine the constitutional amendments themselves. We do not find the one vote one value principle applied there because we have a federal system of government. The veto power of the electors in States of small population, such as that from which Senator Walsh comes, is much greater, voter by voter, than that of electors in New South Wales, Victoria, or indeed any of the larger States. The individual vote there counts for much more than it does in my State of New South Wales, where each vote is discounted by its being but one of a much larger pool. It is interesting that Senator Walsh would like to see this constitutional amendment process, which by its very nature abridges the one vote one value principle, used to achieve the aim upon which his matter of public importance touches.

However, I must observe that the champions of one vote one value, the members of the Australian Labor Party, have no such commitment in regard to their own internal affairs as members of a party, or at the national level in terms of the Federal Conference and the Federal Executive. Those bodies are based on a federal principle rather than representation on a one vote one value basis. For the honourable senator to tell us how we should run our States and the nation, to say that anything other than one vote one value is improper, is hard to understand when one remembers that the honourable senator is a member of a party which quite deliberately moves away from that concept in regard to its own procedures, structure and distribution of power, a party which tends to devalue the power of a party member in New South Wales compared with the power of a Labor member in Western Australia. Let me add the comment that I accept that in many aspects of Australian life the federal structure is appropriate. My own party also has a federal structure. I do not object to that. I am sure that the honourable senator would defend the federal structure of his own party and the inequality as between the value of votes within that party, but that fact should be taken into account when he seeks to advance another argument in regard to electoral redistribution.

The Labor Party is, and always has been, open to further criticism on the basis that, certainly in some States, the unions are able to elect up to 60 per cent of delegates. For example, they may elect that proportion to the New South Wales Labor Party State Conference but the branches may elect only 40 per cent-irrespective of where the membership lies, irrespective of what that does to the principle of one vote one value. In other words, the vote of a union member of the Labor Party is worth more than that of a rank and file member when it comes to matters of internal democracy within that party. These facts should be put on the public record.

The Labor Party has long known about the situation about which it complains today but when it was in office it did very little about it. It tried to propose a referendum on the issue of basing electoral divisions on population rather than numbers of electors. This, in itself, would have moved us away from one vote one value to a very different principle, that of one person one value. The Labor Party went to the people. It did not advocate one vote one value. It advocated a constitutional amendment that would have moved us toward the principle of one person one value. This would have taken into account the number of children and of non-citizens and would have moved away from, and distorted, the electoral system. In some electorates which had large numbers of children or large numbers of non-naturalised immigrants the power of each voter would have been greater than that of a voter in another electorate with a different demographic pattern. In areas with a high concentration of children and non-citizens the votes of electors would have been overvalued compared with those of people who live in electorates with few children and few non-citizens.

The Labor Party put that proposal to referendum. It took the action which Senator Walsh says should be taken. It gave the Australian people an opportunity to decide whether they wanted to move towards the principle of one person one value. The referendum proposal was to apply not only to the Federal Parliament but also to parliaments throughout Australia. I have before me the results of the referendum. I notice that in only one State in Australia did the voters accept the proposition. In that one State it was accepted by only 50.55 per cent-in other words, by a majority of just over one-half of one per cent-and a majority failed to be obtained in the other States. The people of Australia, having considered the proposition, the trade-offs and what was involved all round, decided that a federal level we would not amend the Constitution in the way in which the Labor Party sought. What are we to do? We have the result of a referendum conducted to test the will of the people. The result said: 'No change'.

I come back to what I said previously. I do not have the power to tell New South Wales, where I live, Queensland or Victoria how to set their electoral boundaries. Those are properly matters for those States to determine. They are matters which, the people have determined at a referendum, should properly remain within the powers of those States to determine. I will not get into a domestic argument in this Senate about what is going on in a particular State in relation to a particular redistribution. That is the responsibility of that State. Senator Walsh talked about Western Australia. By raising this matter of public importance he tried to put into the Hansard record his own views of a situation in a State and his vitriolic hatred of the Government of that State. But it is not a matter in which we, as a Federal Parliament, have any standing, on which we can comment or in relation to which we can move. When it was put to the people of Australia at a referendum, they said that was the way they wanted it to be. The States which move in that way will have the authority to do so, will have the responsibility for doing so and will be answerable to their electors in due course for anything they do.

If it is the view of Senator Walsh that a redistribution that any State wants to bring in is deficient, and if he can convince the citizens of that State that that is the case, they will have the remedy at an appropriate time when an election is due. I return to the words of the matter of public importance which sought some Commonwealth action in relation to this matter. Part of Senator Walsh's matter of public importance, as written, speaks of 'The need for the Commonwealth Government to initiate moves'. There were moves. This matter was tested by the Australian people. They have determined that the authority should remain with the States, and that is our view of the matter.

The Commonwealth Government, for its part, is concerned with electoral matters. Within the area of my portfolio I draw the attention of the Senate to the statement made at the time of the last election policy speech when, acting on the advice of the National Aboriginal Conference, the elected body of Aboriginals, we had a recommendation that voluntary electoral enrolment of Aboriginals be changed to compulsory enrolment. That is a matter within the authority and responsibility of the Commonwealth. It was recommended to us by the National Aboriginal Conference. It is a move which will put Aboriginals in the same position as all other Australians. Of course, it is a matter which the Government has promised to legislate for. It is something which is within our area of responsibility and in relation to which we will move. The rest of the matter of public importance had very little to do with this Federal Government and with its responsibilities. I believe the honourable senator made out no significant case. Therefore, I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Colston from moving forthwith the motion of which he gave notice this day.
Before Question Time this afternoon I gave notice that I would move the following motion:

That the Senate requests the Commonwealth Government to enter into immediate negotiations with the Queensland Government to arrive at an appropriate financial formula to enable the continuation of the longstanding free hospital system in Queensland.
Standing Order 448 states, in part:
In cases of urgent necessity, any Standing or Sessional Order or Orders of the Senate may be suspended on Motion, duly made and seconded, without Notice:

This afternoon I just want to outline in brief why this is a case of urgent necessity and why I have thus moved that Standing Orders be suspended. Under normal circumstances the motion of which I gave notice this afternoon before Question Time would be placed on the Notice Paper and brought forward at some time in the distant future. It could be debated late this year or, if there were sufficient notices of motion on the Notice Paper, it could be debated even next year. But for a motion of the type of which I gave notice this afternoon, that is definitely not satisfactory. It is important that the Senate now make a request as outlined in my notice of motion. It should do so at this time because a request made later would not be valid.

We in this chamber are representatives of the various States. If the States are being subjected to hardship by the Federal Government, it is important that we, as representatives of those States, immediately bring that hardship to the mind of the Government, show our opposition to it, express our attitudes in such a way and outline the course of action we consider should be followed to rectify that hardship. The urgency surrounding my moving for suspension of Standing Orders has arisen from a number of factors. I would like to outline some of them. Firstly, we are fast approaching the end of the autumn session. Under normal circumstances such a motion would not be debated before we returned in August. The Government should be aware of the Senate's request, should this motion be passed, well before then and well before the Budget discussions commence.

Secondly, announcements were recently made in this Parliament about changes in the Government's health policy. One of the consequences of that policy is that the people of Queensland are in danger of losing their long-standing free hospital system unless additional Federal funds are forthcoming. Should the motion to suspend Standing Orders be carried, I will be outlining certain factors surrounding the danger that the Queensland people face by having this system taken away from them. Thirdly, we heard last week an amazing admission that the Government would have made an additional $70m available to the States had the States held out longer at the Premiers Conference. Thus, it does not seem that the Federal Government cannot make funds available to the Queensland Government, as outlined in my notice of motion this afternoon.

Fourthly, I believe from media reports that the Premier of Queensland was to have been in Canberra today to try to convince the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that more Federal finance should be made available to Queensland. I am not aware whether the Queensland Premier has come to Canberra, whether he is still in Brisbane or whether he is somewhere in between. I have made some inquiries and there seem to be different reports, but the fact is that media reports said that the Premier of Queeensland was to come to Canberra today to talk to the Prime Minister about the danger facing the free hospital system in Queensland. That being so, the Senate should be able to determine its opinion on the question I raise so that the Prime Minister is aware of the thoughts of the States' representatives when he is talking to the Premier of Queensland. To make a request of the sort I have outlined in the notice of motion after discussions have concluded, after Mr Fraser has spoken with the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, would be just an academic exercise. A request expressed today would be of practical value.

So far I have dwelt on matters associated with Queensland. Being a representative of Queensland I make no apology for having done so. No doubt senators from other States are acutely aware of the widespread criticism of the Federal Government in their own States. For example, today's midday news reported that the Victorian Premier was being very critical of the Federal Government and saying that the Federal Government's actions were likely to cause him a loss at the next Victorian election. Not only the Victorian Premier and the Queensland Premier have complained but also there have been complaints all over Australia.

At this stage I am not asking senators to record a vote on the motion which I have expressed. I will certainly do that if the motion is debated after this motion for suspension of Standing Orders is decided by the Senate. I am asking the Senate to allow the debate on the motion to proceed forthwith. I will read the motion again because I think it is pertinent that senators know the motion for which they are being asked to suspend Standing Orders. The motion reads:

That the Senate requests the Commonwealth Government to enter into immediate negotiations with the Queensland Government to arrive at an appropriate financial formula to enable a continuation of the longstanding free hospital system in Queensland.

Under Standing Orders, having sought the suspension of Standing Orders it is not possible for me to debate the contents of that motion. I will certainly do so provided the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders is carried. At this stage, I conclude my remarks on my request for the suspension of Standing Orders by indicating that I want the debate on this matter to proceed forthwith because I believe that it is a case of urgent necessity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I am certain that after such an eloquent appeal by Senator Colston the Senate will accept the proposition that the Standing Orders should be suspended. It interests me, of course, that the proposition before the chamber is of no interest to any Queensland senator on the Government side. Not one of them is present at the moment. I would have thought that they would have had notice of this move to suspend Standing Orders. That merely makes the need for suspension even more urgent. Their absence from the chamber at the moment and their refusal, in fact, to meet with the Queensland Premier at his request outlines the indifference which they show and make the Opposition's proposition even more urgent. Because of such indifference to the Government's action of cutting back the funding which will seriously affect the Queensland hospitals, that action should be debated at the earliest opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The Premier of Queensland invited all-I hope-of the 20 to 22 Government members who represent Queensland in the House of Representatives and the Senate. Only three Government members turned up at the meeting. One was Senator Bonner, a long-time enemy of Mr Bjelke-Petersen or vice versa. I am not quite certain of the relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no enemies, my friend.

—The honourable senator has no enemies. It seems to me that it follows that Mr Bjelke-Petersen must be at fault. Senator MacGibbon turned up. Of course, one would expect the Premier's wife to turn up. She also was there. I put it to honourable senators that only three Government members turned up out of a total representation from Queensland of 20 members.
—They were busy. They had other things to do.

—They were busy and they had other priorities. In view of what the honourable senator is saying they did not make the future of the free hospital system in Queensland a priority. Of course, that will be to their disadvantage. It seems that the Premier of Queensland has now threatened their political future, which also makes the matter serious. To bring my remarks back in order, it is a matter of urgency that we should debate the proposition forthwith. For that reason I have pleasure in seconding the motion. By this time I do not doubt that the Government has awoken to the seriousness of the matter Senator Colston has put before us. If the matter is not to be debated today the Government will have to put the case for debating it at some other time-we expect this week. My suggestion is that we should debate the matter now. It is extremely urgent. The States are in revolt. The Premier of Queensland is threatening to come into conflict with criminal law in Queensland and, I think, with the Australian Constitution by threatening his members that if they do not come to order in this matter he will make certain that they do not receive an endorsement in the future. So the matter is serious on two counts. It is serious in that the Queensland hospital system is at risk. I cannot give honourable senators any information as to how much it is at risk because I would offend against the Standing Orders if I were to say that in Queensland, apparently--
—You would be offending.

—No, I would be offending if I were to show that Queenslanders receive $68 per head whereas the national average is $87. If that is not urgent and does not demand the suspension of Standing Orders, I do not know what is. The proposition before the chamber is for the suspension of Standing Orders so that I can go into more detail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to the two honourable senators who have spoken because, with the exception of the last minute, it is the first time in this place that I have heard a debate on a motion to suspend Standing Orders under Standing Order 448 in which people have kept their remarks within the Standing Orders, more or less. I am very grateful to the honourable senators for so doing. Senators will know that following the announcement of the Government's new health financing arrangements considerable discussions have been going on. I think there was a meeting of the Commonwealth and all State health Ministers last Friday. I understand that various discussions are continuing between the Commonwealth and various States on this matter. I really do not believe that because of these continuing discussions there is any advantage to either the negotiations or the people of Queensland by acceding to the request made by the honourable senator that Standing Orders should be suspended. Accordingly, we will oppose the motion to suspend Standing Orders. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Colston's) be agreed to.
