SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present papers according to the list circulated to honourable senators. I seek leave to have the list incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
1. Temporary Assistance Authority-Report on certain parts for hearing aids-pursuant to section 30 (1) of the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973.
2. Special Broadcasting Service-Second annual report 1979-80-pursuant to section 79ZH of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1977.
3. Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension-annual report 1979-80.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I understand that it is a normal convention in this Parliament that shadow Ministers have reports of this kind made available to them some two hours before they are tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Statements by leave.

—I think the practice in relation to reports is the same. We have not had that facility as far as the report of the Special Broadcasting Service is concerned. If I might say so, that is not surprising because the Special Broadcasting Service is not an organisation which has complied with the obligations normally imposed on such organisations. The Auditor-General had some remarks to make about the Special Broadcasting Service, the reading of which I commend to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Special Broadcasting Service was set up, I think in 1977, with the opposition of the Australian Labor Party in both Houses of the Parliament. This report covers the financial year 1979-80. It is some ten months since the year in question finished. Much has happened since then. It is not good enough for this report to be tabled at this stage. In fact, it is a matter which I ought to draw to the attention of Senator Rae, as usual, who will no doubt make some comment on it in due course. I also indicate that the report was not available from the office of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) as expected. It highlights the Government's failure to have a firm policy in relation to ethnic and multicultural affairs, especially for television.

I remind the Senate that it was this Senate which said, very wisely in my view, that multicultural television in Australia should not proceed until the inquiry by the Dix committee into the Australian Broadcasting Commission had been completed. We have had no firm statement that the Government has asked the inquiry into the ABC, presided over by Mr Dix, to consider the possibility of the ABC's having a second multicultural television channel. That possibility was canvassed by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. It is a possibility that we on the Opposition side of the chamber will continue to canvass, because it is important that the role of the national broadcasting service be considered as embracing the activities of Channel 0, the multicultural television station operating in Melbourne and Sydney.

All this stems from a commitment by the present Government in line with one of the obsessions-if I may quote from the former Minister for Industrial Relations-of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to provide services to ethnic communities, a commitment which springs from a further obsession about the popularity of the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, amongst ethnic communities which the present Prime Minister has never been able to attain. That obsession has manifested itself in a number of ill-considered attitudes and expressions of policy in relation to broadcasting. This report is another example of that fact.

If I might deal first of all with the question of ethnic radio, I state quite clearly that the consistent position of the Opposition has been that in relation to ethnic radio broadcasting, ethnic communities should be placed in exactly the same position as Australian broadcasters, that is, broadcasters whose ethnic origin is in this country. That is not happening. Ethnic radio broadcasting is substantially embraced in the two radio stations 2EA in Sydney and 3EA in Melbourne. Both those stations are subject to government guidelines and directions; they are particularly subject to guidelines and directions in relation to the political content of programs. That is making members of ethnic communities who wish to broadcast in their own languages second class citizens in this country. No political constraints or guidelines, other than the libel laws, are placed on Australian broadcasters. Political guidelines and government guidelines are imposed on ethnic broadcasters in Australia, and we will place ethnic communities in the same position as Australians in relation to radio broadcasts until we give them the same facilities as community broadcasters in Australia have, namely, the right to have their own licences. The most successful ethnic broadcasting in Australia over many years has been 5UB in Adelaide. As a result of an organisation called Ethnic Broadcasting Inc., as I think it was originally called, the ethnic communities agreed amongst themselves on program times, content, and so on, and ran a very successful ethnic radio service through the facilities provided by 5UB in Adelaide. That is an example of a success story which has not been repeated as a result of the establishment of the Special Broadcasting Service in Australia.

The Special Broadcasting Service legislation contains extraordinary provisions which provide the Minister for Communications with powers to set up, in essence, a government radio. Those provisions should not be included in any legislation of this Parliament. They are totally inconsistent with the legislation establishing the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, and establishing the view that politics should be taken out of broadcasting for Australian broadcasters.

In a letter of transmittal dated 30 June 1980, which is referred to in this document, we are told, that there is 'turbulence over radio'. That is turbulence over ethnic radio, particularly in Sydney. No explanation is given in this report of what 'turbulence' means. I take it it does not mean a sort of crackling noise over the air waves. I think it means that there have been all sorts of rorts in relation to program co-ordinators in Sydney, all sorts of disputes about the news services provided by ethnic radio, and what should and should not be included in those programs. But there is no explanation in this report of what the term 'turbulence' means. Members of this Parliament are asked to interpret the expression 'turbulence' in the report.

Let me make one or two general observations. First of all, the financing of ethnic radio through public broadcasting is a policy to which the Opposition is committed. It is the correct policy for Australia in terms of the considerations that I raised earlier. We need to know more about the present situation. No information is available on the possibility of granting public broadcasting licences to ethnic communities. Secondly, I would like to ask the rhetorical question of whether ethnic communities are happy with their ethnic broadcasting input. Last year the Special Broadcasting Service conducted a survey into this matter. On 4 March 1981 I asked whether a survey had been undertaken amongst the ethnic communities to determine their reaction to ethnic radio. I asked:

if so (a) who commissioned the survey; (b) has the survey been completed and received; (c) who carried out the survey; (d) has the survey been released; and (e) what are the conclusions of the survey.

The Minister for Communications provided answers to those questions. The survey was done for the Special Broadcasting Service. It is complete. It was carried out by Martyn Research and Associates Pty. Ltd. The recipients of the results of the survey included-surprise, surprise-the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), Special Broadcasting Service board members, John Clemenger Pty Ltd and a number of academic institutions. We were then told in the answer to the question that the Special Broadcasting Service issued a Press release on 10 December 1980 summarising the conclusions of the survey, and they are set out in the answer to the question. I ask: Why is the survey not available to the Australian Parliament? Why is it available to John Clemenger Pty Ltd and to certain academics? Why is it available only to members of the Special Broadcasting Service? It would be very interesting to study that survey of the reactions of the ethnic communities to the services provided for them by the Special Broadcasting Service. That survey should be released in full.

In the limited time available one or two other questions should be asked in relation to the provisions of multicultural television. The important question about multicultural television is: Who is it serving? Might I hazard a guess that it is serving middle class, middle brow or slightly high brow Australians living on the North Shore of Sydney and in suburbs such as Eltham in Melbourne who no longer have to go to the Savoy cinema or to the local continental cinema to see continental films. They can do this in their homes as a result of the multicultural television services which have been provided at enormous costs by the Fraser Government. Might I hazard a suggestion that it is not serving ethnic communities at all, or hardly at all. It is another service which is provided to the literate and the esoteric, the inhabitants, as I said, of suburbs such as Eltham and the north shore of Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to mention Hawthorn.

—Not to mention Hawthorn, as Senator Evans points out. But of course we do have a very high multicultural content in the suburb of Hawthorn-surprisingly high-which I am not sure is true of the suburbs of Eltham and the North Shore of Sydney. I think that is probably the correct answer to the question. But there is no information available about that at all. There is no information as to what are the ratings and effectiveness of multicultural television in respect of its stated purpose of serving ethnic communities in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who are familiar with the situation are very much aware of the discontent and the disagreement within the ethnic television panel, or whatever it is called, over this very question. There are those who are pursuing the view that multicultural television should serve the needs of ethnic communities and be directed to those purposes. There are those, like Mr Bruce Gyngell, who has announced himself as a professional authoritarian, who will decide what the content of ethnic television in Australia will be. In fact Mr Gyngell has said that it should be for the clientele that I mentioned a moment or so ago. There is a continuing debate about the effectiveness of multicultural television, which is costing the taxpayer in this country an enormous sum of money.

I refer again to the comments made in the Auditor-General's report and to the questions which were asked in the Senate Estimates Committee about this matter, and in respect of which satisfactory answers were not received. I think I can speak for all honourable senators who attended the relevant Estimates Committee when I say that they left that Committee with the feeling that the Special Broadcasting Service spends money like a many man with no arms, and does so in the interests of the sort of programs to which I referred. I reiterate that there is a need to look at the question of multicultural television in Australia, so-called, in the light of the Dix committee report and the development of a better and more satisfactory national broadcasting service. Might I say that if there is one outstanding thing that has come out of multicultural television in Australia it is the quality of the news services provided by Channel O in Sydney and Melbourne.

Another matter in connection with multicultural television is the question of how long citizens in other capital cities will be denied the service which is now available in Sydney and Melbourne. That is a problem with which all senators will be familiar because the question consistently raised is when those services will be available in other capital cities. My understanding is that that will be an election promise prior to the next election as the very costly effort in Melbourne and Sydney was a promise prior to the last election. The Opposition strongly endorses the idea of ethnic and multicultural broadcasting services and supports government funding to assist those services to provide the best possible programs. We question very much the structure and effectiveness of the present system. Basically we question the way in which the Broadcasting and Television Act continues to exist in its present form. We commend to the Senate in particular the questions which were asked at the Estimates Committee hearing about the Special Broadcasting Service and the unsatisfactory answers which have been received. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH COUNCIL FOR RURAL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Once again South Australia has missed out on having a representative on these types of bodies. I spoke about this matter only last week when I made the plea that South Australia be given a representative on the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You made that plea during the debate on the Bill, didn't you?

—Yes, and I also made the plea during the debate on the report. I did it last week when the Bill was before the chamber. I note, from looking at the list of members of the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension, that Mr Ian McLachlan, a pastoralist from South Australia, was on the Council but resigned in July 1980. I take it that he was replaced by Mr E. N. Fitzpatrick, Director-General of the Department of Agriculture in Western Australia. He was appointed in August 1980 so I take it that he replaced Mr McLachlan. I express my concern that South Australia has missed out again on having a representative on another important body. When I look at the membership of this Council I see that New South Wales has four representatives-Mr Walter Ives, Chairman of the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd, New South Wales; Professor McClymont of the Department of Biochemistry and Nutrition, University of New England; Mr R. M. Watts, Director-General of the Department of Agriculture in New South Wales, and Mr P. D. A. Wright, a pastoralist of New South Wales. Whilst New South Wales has four representatives, Western Australia has one, the Director-General of Agriculture; Victoria one, Dr P. S. Lang, a pastoralist; and the Australian Capital Territory one, Professor Stuart Harris from the Australian National University. Tasmania and Queensland have no representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: When I look at a couple of matters that were picked up by this Council as needing urgent attention, I find that one relates to pig research and another to poultry research. Among those people who make up the Council I cannot see anyone with expertise in poultry. We have a couple of pastoralists on the Council. I would like to know what they know about running a poultry farm. In my view they know absolutely nothing. The Council saw fit to pick out two matters which need urgent attention-pig research and poultry research. The other matter which needs urgent attention is agricultural engineering. No doubt some of the pastoralists on the Council might have some idea about that, but certainly they would have no idea about the needs of the poultry industry. Whilst the poultry industry has been picked out as one which needs more research, we do not have a poultry expert on the Council. I would have thought that somebody from a poultry research station in one of the States, or somebody from the World Poultry Science Association, which has many people who have great expertise, would have been co-opted to the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension.

I do not know whether it is the Government's intention when the terms of office of some of these people expire to appoint someone who has expertise in the poultry and pig industries to carry out this research. From the quick look that I have had at this report I cannot see how long the term of office is for a member of the Commonwealth Council for Rural Research and Extension.

The poultry industry is one of the very few primary industries in this country, as you well know, Mr President, that stand on their own feet. It does not ask for Commonwealth or State subsidies. It has been able to keep its house in order for many years and it is a very viable industry. DEBATE.TITLE: REPORT OF THE ABORIGINAL LAND COMMISSIONER ON THE LIMMEN BIGHT LAND CLAIM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner on the Limmen Bight land claim and seek leave to make a statement in connection with that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This claim was the eighth to be heard by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner under the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The Act provides, amongst other things, a mechanism whereby Aboriginals may lodge claims to unalienated or vacant Crown land in the Northern Territory on the basis of traditional ownership of that land, and for the claims to be heard by the Commissioner who then reports to me and to the Administrator of the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The present claim comprised a narrow strip of coastal land in the Gulf of Carpentaria adjoining the southern boundary of Arnhem Land, together with several off-shore islands and reefs, totalling 768 square kilometres. Approximately 57 per cent of the coastal strip is subject to inundation and mangroves line much of the coast and estuaries. The Commissioner found that the land is unalienated Crown land, that there are Aboriginals who are the traditional owners of the land, and there is a strong attachment by the claimants to most of the land claimed but not to Maria Island-the largest of the off-shore islands. After hearing evidence from some 67 witnesses and having regard to the strength of the claimants' attachment to the land, the Commissioner recommended that the land other than Maria Island be granted to an Aboriginal land trust. Such a grant would benefit not only the traditional owners, who number 150, but also others with a traditional attachment to the land-in all about 250 people.

After carefully considering the Commissioner's report and the transcript of evidence, including the evidence of likely detriment to commercial fishermen and others, I am satisfied that except for a small excision, the land other than Maria Island should be granted to an Aboriginal land trust, as recommended by the Commissioner. In accordance with past practice and as recommended by the Commissioner, I will recommend to the Governor-General that the grant be made to the low water mark. The Commissioner commented that a grant in accordance with his recommendation would be likely to result in some detriment to commercial fishermen, and to residents of the town and district of Katherine who use the rivers in the claim area for recreational or leisure purposes.

The Commissioner has suggested that an excision of 20 hectares near the mouth of the Roper River be provided, primarily for use by commercial fishermen who would benefit by having an area set aside to provide access to the river with space to camp and carry out repairs. This area could also be used by tourists and Katherine residents seeking a place to launch boats. I have decided to excise such an area from the land to be granted and although it will be in the vicinity of an area known as the Number One Landing, I shall make no decision as to its precise location until the Northern Territory Government, the Northern Land Council and representatives of the commercial fishermen have had an opportunity to discuss the matter with a view to reaching a consensus as to the precise boundary. There are two roads on the claim area over which the Commissioner found the public has a right of way and these will be excluded from the grant as required by the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. I shall establish a land trust and will recommend to the Governor-General that a grant of an estate in fee simple in the land be made to the trust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper and the statement.

I want to make a few remarks because I am very concerned at what is happening in respect of the granting of land to Aborigines. On this occasion the Aboriginal Land Commissioner has recommended that an area be precluded from the land to be granted. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has, after consultation with the Northern Territory authorities, agreed with that recommendation because the area of land may be of some value to fishermen and to tourists. Most of the land to be granted is subject to inundation; it is swamp area. Apparently Aborigines get only land which is of no use to anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an absolute misstatement, and it really detracts from what is otherwise a very good event.

—It is my statement and it is somewhat supported by the evidence. We know that at Borroloola when land was excised from a proposed grant to be used as a travelling route by the mining company and the mining company made available a suitable area of land a swap of land took place. On 7 April I asked a question on the granting of land at Mudbura. The Land Commissioner had recommended the granting of land with the exception of one square mile for stock route and quarantine purposes but the Minister in his wisdom did not accept the Commissioner's recommendation. Instead, the Minister decided that five square miles of land should be excluded from the grant. I asked whether the land would be used as a stock route and for quarantine purposes or had some other value. The Minister replied to me by way of a letter. He said that after referring the matter to the Northern Territory Administration it was decided that five square miles would be excluded from the grant. Obviously the decision is made by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, not by the Australian Government. It is pertinent to point out that the Commissioner stated he had made the recommendation on the evidence of the Northern Territory Department of Primary Production. If it is up to a Minister to decide what land is to be granted it will be on the basis of political opportunity or favouritism. The Commonwealth established the Aboriginal Land Commission to get over that sort of problem. We appointed an impartial commissioner who is compelled to make a recommendation on the evidence that is presented to him. The evidence presented to the commissioner in the Mudbura claim indicated that one square mile should be excluded from the grant but the Chief Minister said, after consideration: 'No, we want five square miles'. The Minister has decided to exclude five square miles. I think it is important to point out for the record that the question I asked was without notice but the Minister was unable to reply at the time I asked the question because the grant of land had been approved under the previous Minister. As the present Minister replied to me by way of letter on 5 May 1981, I therefore seek leave to have the reply incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Minister for Aboriginal Affairs Canberra, A.C.T. 2600 5 May 1981
Dear Senator Cavanagh,

On 7 April 1981 you put to me a Question Without Notice concerning the Yingawunarri Mudbura Aboriginal Land Claim. As your question dealt with a decision of the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I undertook to examine the matter and provide you with an answer.

In accordance with the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act the Aboriginal Land Commissioner reports on each land claim to both the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Administrator of the Northern Territory, who in turn passes the report to the Chief Minister's Department. Before any decision is taken on the granting of a claim, the Minister obtains the views of the Northern Territory Government, as it is Northern Territory Crown land which is alienated by the granting of a claim.

In his report on the Yingawunarri Mudbura claim the Aboriginal Land Commissioner did not recommend that one square mile around Pussycat bore be excluded, but he commented that the evidence ''did demonstrate a value in the retention of an area of one mile square or thereabouts around Pussycat bore''. The Northern Territory Acting Chief Minister, after reviewing the Commissioner's report, suggested that a five square mile excision might be more realistic for quarantine purposes, particularly where larger stock numbers are quarantined for an extended period of time. This view was not presented to the Land Commissioner at the time of the hearing. What was put forward, however, by the Northern Territory Department of Primary Production was that a one square mile reserve around Pussycat bore would be the ''absolute minimum'' area required for quarantine purposes.
Senator Chaney was satisfied that the larger excision proposed by the Northern Territory Government was required and announced his decision accordingly. The exclusion is for quarantine purposes only.

Title deeds for the land grant have not yet been prepared. The NT Chief Minister has agreed to close a disused section of road known as the Murranji track, which the Commissioner had found to be a public road and therefore liable for exclusion from the grant. This road passed through some of the best country on the claim and included an important sacred site. Its closure will enable the land concerned to be included in the land grant.

At paragraph 25 of his annual report the Aboriginal Land Commissioner notes that ''there is no inconsistency at all involved in accepting the recommendations and excluding the five square miles''. Questions of competing land use, such as arose during this hearing, must ultimately be decided by government.
Yours sincerely, PETER BAUME
Senator J. L. Cavanagh,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —The only other point I want to make is an important one because it relates to what the Minister said today about discussions with the Northern Land Council. In return for excising an extra four square miles from the grant of land at Mudbura the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has closed a disused section of the road known as the Murranji track which the Commissioner had found to be public road and therefore liable for exclusion from the grant. In exchange for four square miles of land which the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory wants to retain and without any justification on the evidence presented to the Commissioner, there has been a closure of the road. It looks as though following consultation there was a trade off in land which the Northern Territory Administration did not want for land that it does want, contrary to the Commissioner's recommendation. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs made certain recommendations in relation to Kakadu National Park. A uranium mining company found that its activities extended into areas which were not excluded from the Kakadu National Park. The need for its mining operations to be extended was greater than the company thought. That was what it claimed. The Minister, in a statement to the House--
—They cannot have a mine without Aboriginal consent.

—I am trying to make a point. The Minister went there yesterday to hold discussions. I should like to mention that the same thing happened in relation to this claim as happened at Mudbura. There was a trade-off of land. Some area of the escarpment might be granted to Aboriginals as a trade-off to allow the mining company to operate in a particular area. This has nothing to do with impartiality, the consideration of traditional rights and so on. It is a question simply of trading off one area of land for another which the Commissioner found should rightfully belong to Aboriginals. What I am saying is that we do not know the actual findings of the Commissioner in this case, but the Commissioner has recommended the excision of land, possibly with the consent of the Aboriginals. Are the Aboriginals getting a fair deal? Should we establish the position of Aboriginal Land Commissioner to decide such questions but then allow the Government to make the decision? That is the whole point. Although the Act provides that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has the right to make the decisions it would appear that the Northern Territory Chief Minister is making decisions on what land should be given to the Aboriginals. I am fearful because of the rotten deal the Aboriginals in the Northern Territory are getting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cavanagh did not seek leave to continue his remarks. Therefore I should like to speak for a couple of minutes and then seek leave to continue my remarks. We should like to debate this matter at a later stage. I have a couple of points to make. It was very disappointing that the report was not available to us today so that we could examine it. We were given a copy of the statement two hours before it was presented in this place. We have not seen the report although I understand that some copies were made available to other people. I will not take that matter any further.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason the report should have been available today is that there is much to be said about it. I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to give the Senate some assurance that the matter will be brought on for debate fairly soon. I will not press this point strongly in view of private comments made to me by the Minister. He said that we will be able to debate a number of related matters later. A couple of points must be mentioned. Maria Island must be mentioned. Unless we are given further information we must question whether this will be another situation like the Borroloola land claim when the island was given to Mount Isa Mines Ltd against the wishes of the people.

We must ask, as Senator Cavanagh has asked, what will happen to professional fishermen with the excision of this land. We must query this point. We do not know the purpose for the excision of land. We do not know whether another case will arise where the barramundi industry will be interfered with by professional people dragging the rivers. I indicate that members of the Opposition would like this debate brought on fairly soon so we can have an opportunity to examine the document which has been circulating since this morning and have an opportunity to discuss these matters with the Aboriginal people involved. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill is an omnibus Bill by which the Government seeks to extend and update the Quarantine Act: To provide comprehensive quarantine and disease control arrangements for the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Territory; to give effect to outstanding recommendations for legislative change put forward by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in its report on the adequacy of quarantine; and to make additional provisions and amendments and to provide additional powers which are required for effective quarantine administration and enforcement in Australia. The Bill is a reflection of the Government's strong commitment to an efficient quarantine service which must continue to play an effective and major role in Australia's social and economic well-being.

Honourable senators will know that a high security animal quarantine station is under construction in the Territory of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The station will provide a safe means of achieving genetic improvement in our economic livestock through the importation of genetically superior animals from disease risk areas of the world. Without the security of an offshore station, importation of such animals from all but a very few countries could not be contemplated. Current estimates are that construction of the station will be completed in September 1981. Security of the station depends on appropriate quarantine and other disease control arrangments for the Territory as a whole. Because of the integrated nature of the arrangements which are required the legislation must encompass animal, plant, general and human quarantine areas and authorise all necessary measures to prevent the introduction or spread of diseases affecting animals, plants and man. The Government has decided that these comprehensive quarantine arrangements would best be achieved by extending to the Territory, with amendment where necessary for Territory application, the relevant powers, functions and requirements of the Quarantine Act. The proposed legislation would differentiate between Australia and the Territory to ensure that suitable controls can be exercised over the movement of vessels, people, animals, plants and goods between Australia and the Territory.

The Bill also makes provision for the internal control of diseases and pests of animals and plants in the Territory. These powers are exercised in Australia by State authorities under State legislation and form an integral part of Australia's overall animal and plant protection framework. These necessary State-type powers are not currently available in the Territory. I draw the attention of honourable senators to clause 4 of the Bill which provides for the application of the Quarantine Act in the Territory. Clause 7 of the Bill amends section 13 of the Act to authorise the Governor-General to make proclamations which will prohibit or control the importation of animals, plants or goods into the territory from Australia or overseas. I would like to emphasise that for the purposes of entry into Australia of persons, vessels, goods, animals or plants the Cocos Islands will continue to be regarded as an overseas place under the amended legislation. Similarly Australia will be an oversea place for the purpose of entry into Cocos. Clause 41 provides for the making of regulations relating, inter alia, to the internal State-type stock and plant disease control measures to which I have referred. The system for setting the fees which are to apply for the management and maintenance of animals at the quarantine station will also be provided for in the regulations.

I would now like to turn to the report of the Senate Committee on National Resources. This report 'The Adequacy of Quarantine And Other Control Measures To Protect Australia's Pastoral Industries From The Introduction And Spread Of Exotic Livestock And Plant Diseases' was tabled in November 1979. The Committee recommended, inter alia, that the Quarantine Act be amended to eliminate problems relating to the granting of pratique and the lack of certain powers for quarantine officers, and to provide legislative support for contemporary quarantine problems not currently covered by the Act. The Government's reponse to the Committee's report was tabled in this chamber in September 1980. The Government pointed out that although many of the important matters referred to by the Committee had been taken up by the Quarantine Amendment Act 1979, the need for further legislative action would be closely examined in the light of the Committee's concern.

The Bill before the Senate proposes amendments developed in the light of the Committee's views. It follows an extensive review of relevant legislation and current quarantine requirements and problems. I would like to highlight some of the more important changes: Firstly there are new arrangements regarding imported animals, plants and goods which will ensure that they remain under quarantine control until specifically released. Presently the granting of pratique to the vessel releases all the goods on board. The Bill also makes provision for pratique to be granted by radio message as well as by conventional means. New powers for the examination of imported animals, plants and goods before and after release from quarantine are included in clauses 24 and 27. An examination under these provisions would include sampling and testing. The Bill provides power for quarantine officers to ask questions, require documents or samples and undertake tests in relation to goods which are, or are suspected to have been, subject to quarantine. There are also new powers under warrant to enter premises for the purpose of examining goods, including animals and plants which are subject to quarantine. Finally, the power to order imported goods, animals and plants into quarantine on disease grounds are clarified and expanded. Mr President, I believe that these and other amendments contained in the Bill, taken in conjunction with the amendments effected in the Quarantine Amendment Act 1979 meet the specific concerns raised by the Senate Committee on National Resources which are appropriate to quarantine legislation.

The Bill also rectifies a number of other deficiencies identified during the Department's examination. Section 20 of the Act makes it an offence for the master of an overseas vessel arriving in Australia to enter any port other than a port that has been declared to be a first port of entry. It is not an offence to land anywhere on the coast other than at a port. Clause 15 would extend the provision to make it an offence for the master of an oversea vessel to beach the vessel or to anchor or moor the vessel above the low water mark around the shore of Australia or the Cocos Islands, excepting under stress of weather or other reasonable cause. Section 69A of the Act provides for compensation under certain circumstances for goods, including animals or plants, which are destroyed under the Act for disease reasons. These arrangements were introduced in 1979 to encourage co-operation from owners and to facilitate prompt action in exotic disease eradication operations. The appropriateness of these compensation provisions for imported livestock species and certain other classes of imported animals has been reviewed. Advice to the Government is that no other major livestock importing nation-that is, Canada, the United States of America, New Zealand and the United Kingdom-compensates where destruction of imported livestock is ordered for disease reasons at a quarantine station. Inquiries in Australia indicate that this eventuality, should it occur at an Australian mainland station or the Cocos Island station, is an insurable risk.

In the circumstances, the Government has concluded that it is reasonable for Australian importers of livestock and certain other classes of animals to carry the risk of destruction in a quarantine station under the Act as part of total importation costs. The Bill therefore provides at clause 33 that imported horses, asses, mules, pigs and ruminants, animals imported for a zoo or circus, or animals imported for research will not qualify for compensation if they are destroyed at a quarantine station under the Act and had been in quarantine at all times between their importation and destruction. Compensation will still be paid for these types of animals if after release from the quarantine station they are later ordered into quarantine and destroyed. Compensation will also be available under the Act for other imported species such as cats and dogs, lawfully imported and for all animals of Australian origin.

I now draw the attention of honourable senators to clause 38 of the Bill. During the course of coastal surveillance operations, a number of unauthorised landings in Australia have been reported. In the main, these breaches of quarantine legislation have been by foreign fishing vessels. These quarantine breaches by small craft in remote areas of Australia pose grave threats of the introduction of major exotic diseases. Foot and mouth disease, Newcastle disease and rabies are some of the diseases from which Australia is free but which are well established in adjacent countries. Much of our northern coastline is backed by economically important livestock areas which are also abundantly populated with feral animals and insect vectors capable of transmitting any introduced exotic disease. For this reason any reports of an unauthorised landing evoke a quarantine investigation of the landing place and appropriate measures to minimise the possibility of disease introduction.

Quarantine actions of this type have highlighted serious practical deficiencies in the relevant enforcement and penalty provisions of the Act. Amongst other things, powers to apprehend or detain vessels used in connection with major contraventions of the Act are inadequate. Also there are no provisions which compel persons on such vessels to comply with directions regarding quarantine clearances. As matters now stand quarantine measures can be nullified by non-compliance. Further, present penalties have little practical relevance or deterrent value in the situations which have been encountered. Accordingly clause 38 of the Bill inserts new section 75A which authorises the detention of vessels of less than 45 metres in length or aircraft which are believed on reasonable grounds, to have been used in or in connection with certain specified major breaches of quarantine legislation. The Minister for Health may, after consideration of the circumstances, direct that the vessel be returned to the master or owner. In other cases the vessel will be forfeited to the Crown unless the owner brings an action in a court of competent jurisdiction for the return of the vessel within a prescribed period and the court finds that the vessel was not used in connection with a breach of the Act.

The new section also empowers quarantine officers to destroy any goods which may present a disease risk or any animals or plants which are on board, or which he believes have been on board the detained vessel. Honourable senators should note that at section 75C an approved person is also empowered to destroy overseas animals which he locates on any prescribed sea vessel in Australian waters, unless he is satisfied that arrangements exist for the security of those animals. The possible escape of such animals present an unacceptable disease risk. These new provisions demonstrate the Government's determination to provide the strongest possible deterrent to unauthorised landings in Australia and to the disease threat that these and other activities pose. The Government is not prepared to tolerate activities of this kind which place our economic and social livelihood at risk.

Finally, I draw the attention of honourable senators to clause 35 of the Bill. This clause inserts a new section which relates to the provision of quarantine information to travellers to Australia. Honourable senators will be aware that unauthorised importations of animal and plant materials by overseas visitors or returning Australians are a major potential source of disease introduction. Large quantities of such materials are intercepted at our international ports of entry. Better co-operation from an informed travelling public is essential if we are to continue to maintain the quarantine security on which our economic wellbeing depends. As one step towards this objective the Government is conducting a major national quarantine publicity campaign to increase awareness and encourage individual responsibility and self-regulation in quarantine matters. The Government has now decided on additional measures to ensure that travellers to Australia are informed of our quarantine requirements.

Accordingly, proposed section 74AA requires the masters of all vessels travelling to Australia, including aircraft, to advise everyone on board of our quarantine requirements. The content and form of such advice are to be in accordance with approvals of the Director of Quarantine. Mr President, the Bill before the Senate is a most important piece of legislation. It would provide our quarantine service with increased capacity to meet Australia's present and future needs. It is a Bill which should receive support from all sections of the Senate. Mr President, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AMENDMENT (TENDERS) BILL 1981CUSTOMS SECURITIES (PENALTIES) BILL 1981CUSTOMS UNDERTAKINGS (PENALTIES) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose these Bills which give effect to one of the key decisions made by the Government last year with respect to assistance to the textile, clothing and footwear industry. The scheme introduced by the legislation involves a two-tier quota system. First of all, there is a base quota made up of 85 per cent of the initially established quotas for each item, which base quota is to be allocated among established importers. The remaining tier involves what is described as a tender quota which constitutes the remaining portion of 15 per cent and which may be extended in practice in certain circumstances in the future. It is to be available for sale on a Dutch auction basis to bona fide importers, the idea being to provide easier and more flexible access to import quotas by both new importers and those already in the market who are wanting to expand their market share.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition approaches any scheme involving substantial protection for any Australian industry with a very considerable degree of caution because any such protection does, of course, involve by its very nature substantial penalties for Australian consumers. But we are all too well aware that over 120,000 jobs are at stake in the textile, clothing and footwear industry. A great many of those jobs, of course, are in regional areas, especially in Victoria, where there simply is no conceivable alternative employment available now and nor will there be in the reasonably foreseeable future on an appropriate scale. We have also consistently supported the view of the Crawford study group on structural adjustment that whatever might be the strength of the case for a longer term reduction in protection in industries such as this, drastic reductions in protection simply cannot be contemplated at times of high unemployment. The present rate of over 6 per cent-it is much higher than that if one includes invisible unemployment-is simply impossibly high by any historical or, indeed, any humane standard. Furthermore, we in the Opposition, focusing now more narrowly on the legislation before us, have taken the view that the specific kind of protection that is involved in import quotas is appropriate to the kind of industry which we have here, although it may not be so for other industries in other circumstances. It probably is the case that only quota protection of this type is likely to produce the kind of certainty which will encourage the textile, clothing and footwear industry to invest, over time, in new plant of such a kind as will enable it to become more competitive in the future.

All that said, we nonetheless have some reservations about this legislation or, if not the legislation itself, about the administrative and larger economic context in which it is introduced. Let me briefly indicate what those reservations are. There is no need for me to go on in any detail about this matter since these and other points I have made have in fact been canvassed already in the other place. There are three or four short points I wish to make. The first point is that there are clear opportunities for profiteering by those privileged persons holding base quotas unless the rate of duty on the base quota for each item is reconsidered annually and is adjusted in line with the trend of prices that is in fact revealed by the tender system. Some indication from the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) that this is in fact intended, although it does not appear on the face of the legislation, I think, would be welcomed and in the public interest. The second point is that there is a real prospect, unless the scheme is again properly administered, that a number of large importers will tie up the market here and that small firms will be excluded. The crucial factor is the amount of the security which will be required. Like my colleague in the other place, I repeat the call of Mr Clive Rodger of the Apparel Importers and Manufacturers Association of Australia, who has strenuously made the point that the amounts required by way of security should be calculated with this consideration very centrally in mind.

The third point I make is that if the right to buy and sell quotas is not to be abused and exploited by persons who are not bona fide importers, the formal provisions of the new legislation, as effective as they may well be on paper, will have to be enforced. There must be very grave doubts about the capacity of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to do this when it, like every other department in the Federal Government at the moment, is subject to the savagery of the razor gang cuts, in particular the three per cent wind-back on administrative expenses to which all departments and authorities are to be subject and, beyond that, of course, the further 2 per cent reduction in staff ceilings.

The Auditor-General's report for March 1981 demonstrated with fairly breathtaking clarity just how the staff ceilings that had already been applied prior to the razor gang have had a quite devastating effect on the efficiency of a number of departments charged with law enforcement activities and revenue collection activities. It is a very real concern on the part of the Opposition and, I imagine, many of those in the industry too that the Department simply will not have the resources available to it to engage in this new form of administration which is involved in this quota scheme.

The final point I make is a more general one and that is that we cannot but notice the degree to which the Government is willing to protect the private sector from the rigours of free market competition in areas such as this but at the same time is engaged on what can really be described only as a rampage of deregulation when it comes to beneficial and proper interventions in that market by bodies such as the Prices Justification Tribunal, which is now to be abolished, and by the Trade Practices Commission, which is to be emasculated. The private sector just simply should not be allowed to have it both ways in this respect. If the private sector is to be nurtured in the public interest by protective arrangements such as those embodied in this legislation, in the public interest it should also be subject to that degree of discipline which is enforced by organisations such as the Prices Justification Tribunal and the Trade Practices Commission where that discipline is manifestly unable to be administered or is unwillingly administered by the market. But to ask the Government to act in a way which does not give the private sector the advantages of its beneficence, both coming and going, is of course to ask the Government to act both rationally and in the national interest. Regrettably, they are not characteristics which we have all too often been able to recognise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take issue with Senator Evans on only one point, and that is the need to distinguish between free competition and fair competition, particularly when most of that competition comes from countries whose governments highly subsidise an export, quite often for the purpose of merely generating hard currencies. But I come back to the main point. In August last year the Government announced its decision in relation to the Industries Assistance Commission report on the clothing, textile and footwear industries. Although basically the Government rejected the main thrust of that report, which advocated, honourable senators may recall, progressive reduction in protection of those industries, it took up a number of features which it believed or acknowledged were desirable. The Customs Amendment (Tenders) Bill, the Customs Securities (Penalties) Bill and the Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Bill reflect those Government decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: But we must recognise that the Government, in its wisdom, as from 1 January 1982 has provided a 7-year period of protection to those industries. The Government believes, I must say, contrary to a great deal of industry advice, in the need to open up the quota area. In its endeavour to do this it has recognised two distinct types of quota. The first type of quota is a base quota, and the second type is a quota based on a tender system. In the base quota, 85 per cent will initially be reserved, which will establish a quota ceiling. This 85 per cent is based on data for the year 1979-80 and will apply as from 1982. The purpose is to protect those industries which have been established in the trade over a number of years and to provide a degree of continuity. Some argue that possibly the 85 per cent is too high and that it gives, as Senator Evans rightly said, an opportunity to trade and to profit unduly in the event of substantial price rises. I acknowledge that point.

The second feature contains a tender element, and this takes up the remainder. The remainder will be a minimum of 15 per cent. This remainder is subject to two additional factors. A growth factor is built into the 15 per cent. Another factor is called the liberalisation factor. Nowhere in the legislation do we see this 85 per cent or the remainder, which is essentially 15 per cent plus the growth of liberalised factors, mentioned. That comes by way of ministerial statement. So I believe that with a change of government heart or attitude this possibly could change, although I say it may be undesirable to change it at this point. This leads me to believe that we will see a general liberalisation of the import quota system. I think this is further evidenced by virtue of introducing a tender system providing for these two factors, a growth factor and a liberalisation factor.

I think we also have to recognise that it is right and proper that what economists would refer to as the scarcity rent value accrues not to individuals but to the Government. As to the 85 per cent, it accrues to individuals. Under the tender system, the scarcity rent value accrues to the Government. That is right and proper. However, some critics tend to say: 'Is this not really immoral? Is it not really a duty on a duty, in effect a double duty?' We must recognise that factor, but I believe the argument that the scarcity rent value should accrue to the Government is the superior argument and must prevail. Therefore, taking these factors into consideration, one must assume that over the next six or seven years there will be a liberalisation of quotas, which will open up import competition.

A further feature of the program which I believe deserves comment, but reference to which is not found in the Bills before us today, is the new system of paying a bounty on cotton spun yarns. It is to be regretted that there is so little understanding of some of the problems in this area and that it is taking so long to bring into effect, despite the goodwill on the part of government officers, who are trying to establish an acceptable scheme, and the industry itself. There is a genuine fear that if the suggested levels in this area of activity prevail, this system, which is regarded as one of the more efficient in the textile industry, will be quite uncompetitive. We would then be faced with the dilemma of having a scheme which, because it has not been properly devised, will run counter to the genuine philosophy of providing adequate protection for at least the next seven years. Few people recognise the large degree of rationalisation and restructuring that has taken place in the clothing, textile and footwear industries. The media continue to peddle this free trade argument, as do importers, consumer groups, farmer organisations, retailers, resource-based operatives or industries--

TALK.START.PARA: —And some Government senators.

—And some Government senators, from Western Australia in particular. They fail to recognise the impact that inevitably this restructuring will have on people's lives. People are our most important commodity, although that is possibly a bad term to use. Too often, the decisions of the Industries Assistance Commission fail to recognise the social consequences which may flow therefrom. The Government should place far more emphasis on the need for the Commission to bear this in mind. I refer, for instance, to the tremendous dislocation such decisions can produce, especially in decentralised areas, where opportunities are fairly limited. All the developed nations which desire to improve, or at least maintain, their standard of living enjoy a high degree of protection. We acknowledge that that is true of Australia, but it is also true of the United States of America, the countries of the European Economic Community and Japan.

SPEECH.PARA: Many groups which advocate free trade themselves enjoy a large measure of protection, though in a different form. Currently there is much news of change in the banking industry. That industry is possibly the most highly protected of any in Australia, but that protection is spoken of very little. The industry is surrounded by a plethora of government legislation and regulation. The primary industries also enjoy considerable income tax incentives. Again the service industries, such as the Public Service, insurance companies and the like, enjoy a high degree of protection if only by virtue of location. To import cheap labour is against the Australian philosophy. Apparently it is one thing to import cheap goods but contrary to our philosophy to import cheap labour. I am not advocating that that should be done but pointing out that that inconsistency of argument often prevails among those who advocate the freeing of trade.

That leads me to the observation that it is quite incredible that at a time when employers potentially have many jobs to offer the unemployed, whose problems are accelerating daily, the wage mechanism appears to be getting out of kilter. Although employers say, 'Yes, we want to put on more people', they have not the resources or returns to justify doing so. Unless we can resolve that dilemma in our day and age we will be in for some major problems. We must overcome it. We have resources to develop. We have manpower-many of whom are unemployed at this time-but there is something wrong with the pricing mechanism, in that the price of certain types of labour is being bid so high that those who are essentially unskilled are finding it extremely difficult to enter the work force. Once they have been out of the work force for a considerable period after leaving school it becomes extremely difficult for them to re-enter it. It is far easier to go from one job to another than it is to go from a state of being unemployed to one of being employed.

I should like to draw attention to certain points that are not generally recognised. They relate to dealings with developing countries. Those countries, because of preferential rates of duty, have better access to the Australian market than most people recognise. From the beginning of the seven year program of protection, quotas in some areas will be increased annually by between one per cent and 9 per cent. Therefore, let us not believe that an overall blanket of protection is to prevail. Many representatives of Australian industry are claiming that the protection afforded them is inadequate. The free trade element must be very happy with this Bill and with the fact that quotas will be raised annually by between one per cent and 9 per cent. These indeed represent large figures.

I wish now to refer to a matter that was raised by John Collins, the chief executive of Bradmill Industries, which is one of the largest textile organisations in Australia. In the company's annual report, speaking of the developing countries, he states:

Around 150 countries will be able to sell products on to the Australian market without controls by quota at prices even more competitive than other imports. The result of this could be extremely damaging to the very industries the assistance program is designed to protect.

The Government needs to re-assess, on an appropriate needs basis, a formula for determining the eligibility criteria for classification as a 'developing country'. Too many nations are taking advantage of this particular provision. Potentially, their actions could throw thousands of people in Australia out of jobs. We need to re-assess the basis for deciding which countries are truly developing and which are not.

Since 15 per cent of the quota will be offered for sale by way of tender, the Customs Amendment (Tenders) Bill is necessary in order to formulate the administrative arrangements for determining the operations of a tender system. Basically, the higher the price tendered by a person the higher will be his priority in relation to the allocation of the quantum for which he tenders. However, the price will be determined by the lowest acceptable tender submitted. Naturally, it will be necessary to ensure that those who tender will give undertakings that they will take up the amount for which they have tendered. To ensure that they do so, there must be appropriate penalties. Hence the need for two of these Bills-the Customs Securities (Penalties) Bill and the Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Bill.

The legislation also provides an opportunity for transferring rights to import goods at concessional rates of duty, but before that can be done the Minister will require two types of undertakings: Firstly, a security for the payment of the penalty and, secondly, a security or an undertaking to import the quantity at the price which was tendered for. That is designed to prevent an underutilisation of the particular tender. I believe two major reservations have emerged as a result of this contemplated legislation. First, large companies could dominate the tender system. However, in answer to that, the small and specialist importer or retailer can bid fairly high because he has a market in which he can establish a satisfactory margin. On the other hand, there would be a real danger should the G. J. Coles and Woolworths of this area bid too high. As they are going to take up the bulk of the tender, if they bid too high they might become uncompetitive in the market. This will be the discipline which will prevent them from essentially bidding too high a price and which will determine the allocation price for all tenders, including the specialist tenders.

The other reservation that some people have is that quotas could be bought by merchant banks, which could resell them to the highest bidder. Whether that is an objection remains to be seen. The merchant bank has to provide the undertakings and the security. Should it fail to sell off those rights, it would have to pay the penalty. If it bid too high it would not establish an adequate market, would lose on the deal and, next time round, would be less attracted to the particular system. I commend these Bills to the Senate, but only as part of a trade-off. That trade-off was a recognition that the Government in the main would provide an adequate measure of protection. We could not get as much as we had hoped for and I regard this legislation as a bit of a quid pro quo for the main thrust of what we were seeking, which was the protection of jobs in the textile, clothing and footwear industry, to provide a degree of security to the people working in the industry. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support of the legislation. I draw attention to one or two remarks which my colleagues have made, in particular Senator Watson's concerns, obviously sincerely expressed, for the people with whom he has contact and who are employed in industry not only in Tasmania but also in other parts of Australia. The government policy incorporated in this legislation is designed to express the conscious concern of the Government about the disruptive effects of any major changes which could occur in the kind of marketing proposals that other people may have been proposing. Consequently, the setting of a base quota at 85 per cent, with a freeing up of the 15 per cent tender quota, appears to be a reasonable approach to the problem and certainly heads down the track of establishing a freer market in the textile, clothing and footwear industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly Senator Watson was seeking some kind of information from me with regard to the Government's policy on future direction. All I can say in that regard is that understandably the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) will be reviewing this whole matter in his statement with regard to the scheme which will be outlined following the passage of this legislation and its assent by the Governor-General. Senator Watson also made a point in connection with the accrual of the revenue to the Government as a result of the tender system operating. Of course, that is in line with current practice and certainly would help to stem abuse of the system.

Senator Evans made three or four points during the debate. He sought some advice with regard to some reservations he had. The first of those concerned an annual appraisal of the duty on the base quota. I am advised that the approach of the Government in this regard will not be to conduct that method of appraisal but from time to time to consider the penalty rates of duty upon the recommendations of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee. Senator Evans also mentioned the privileged position of those people who are already in the scheme and who will continue in it on the basis of 85 per cent of their imports established in the year 1979-80. The point here is that this is a step in the right direction towards freeing up the system which does not seek to disrupt the industry. The argument revolves around that particular question. Some of Senator Evans's predecessors in government had more radical approaches to this question. We have perhaps seen some of the results of that and we can refer him to that experience for his own benefit.

Finally, Senator Evans mentioned the ability of the staff of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to manage the system. I am advised that that will occur through redeployment of people in the Department. It will be necessary to do so only on a relatively short term basis-for approximately two months per annum. Consequently, it is likely to be easily encompassed within the Department's normal operations. I wish the legislation a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or request.
