TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I suggest that we debate the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill cognately. Separate questions will be put at the conclusion of the debate.
—That course is agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill are not controversial and the Opposition will not oppose them. The purpose of the Bills is to provide adjustments for cost increases since the Acts, which these Bills are amending, were introduced and to provide some other non-contentious amendments. However, because of other policies and intentions announced recently by the Government with respect to the structure and funding of both secondary and tertiary education in this country the Opposition will be moving an amendment to each of the Bills. At this stage for the benefit of the Senate I will read these amendments. With regard to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1981 I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add ', but the Senate condemns the reduction in the activities of the Schools Commission as announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions in that:

(1) the contraction of the information collection and dissemination activities of the Commission constitutes an obstacle to the debate on education policy and will limit accountability for education expenditure, and
(2) the withdrawal of the administrative functions of the Commission at the State level will limit and downgrade the services the Commission provides particularly to the non-government sector'.
In respect of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill the Opposition will move the following amendment:

At the end of the motion, add ', but the Senate condemns the ill-considered and grossly inequitable changes to the funding, organisation and financing of students in tertiary education as announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions, in that:
(1) the re-introduction of fees is not only a breach of an election undertaking but will grossly disadvantage students with limited means and will compromise Australia's research effort;
(2) the gutting of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme will confirm tertiary education as the preserve of the rich, and

(3) the heavy-handed threat in the review to 30 colleges of advanced education is based on the wholly false premise that the consolidation of single purpose colleges will result in cost savings in spite of the Tertiary Education Commission's advice to the contrary'.

As I said at the outset, the Opposition does not oppose the provisions of the Bills. There are four major provisions in the first Bill. Firstly, the first instalment, that is, $7.4m for this year, of the $25m capital assistance for non-government schools promised before the last Federal election is contained in this Bill. The Opposition is not opposed to that provision. Secondly, there is a compression of the current six levels of non-government schools for the purposes of Schools Commission funding into three levels. Again, that is not opposed by the Opposition. The third provision is a new program of assistance for the education of severely handicapped children both at home and in institutions. That provision is warmly welcomed by the Opposition. Fourthly, there is the support for non-profit, part time, ethnic schools which are providing supplementary education in community languages and cultures. Again, the Opposition strongly welcomes this provision because it has long recognised the great value to our multicultural community in Australia of the Saturday schools or the ethnic schools, as they are known. It seems to us to be a very sensible measure of support to provide some financial backing to these schools which are undoubtedly contributing to the general education welfare of our multicultural society.

However, as I have indicated, the Opposition is severely critical of the Government's general attack on our education system, both secondary and tertiary. In the secondary education system we have seen government policies, particularly those announced last week, which will result in a lowering of standards, especially in government schools; in reducing access to later secondary education, again particularly in government schools; and in a dismantling of national education programs such as those carried out by the Curriculum Development Centre and the Australian Schools Commission. This dismantling not only represents a waste of public investment of the public money that has been invested in developing those two national programs but also, and perhaps more importantly, represents a waste, a squandering, of the personal resources of skill and experience which have gone into the development of both the Curriculum Development Centre and the Australian Schools Commission.

We believe the Federal Government is withdrawing, by these and other methods, from its statutory, primary obligation-I repeat that it has a statutory obligation-to provide to all without fees or religious tests public education at the highest possible standard. It is very clear that the overall effect of the various onslaughts of the Fraser Government on secondary education in this country will be the reduction of standards in government schools. I repeat that the Federal Government has a statutory and primary obligation to ensure that education of the highest possible standard is available to all without fees or religious tests. When we look at the tertiary scene we see a similar onslaught by the Fraser Government. The Fraser Government is intent on destroying research and development in this country. It could not have picked a worse possible time in terms of the Australian economy to mount this onslaught. Day after day in this place we debate problems in the economy. It is very clear to all of us that many of those problems arise because of the old-fashioned, antiquated nature of a great deal of our manufacturing sector and, indeed, of many aspects of our primary industry.

If we need anything in Australia at this time it is new skills, ability to research and develop new industries and to improve, update and introduce more sophisticated techniques into the whole running of our economy. At the time when we need these new skills and new industries to provide employment and these new avenues of creating revenue in this country, what do we see? We see an onslaught on research and development, on the ability of universities and other institutions in this country to carry out research and development and on the ability of gifted, highly motivated individuals to develop their skills and experience to a point where they would be able to compete with the skills and experience of other developed countries. I cannot express strongly enough my criticism of that development. We are reducing the already low level of advanced skills available in our economy. I will be making some detailed comments on that matter later. Let us lay to rest once and for all the idea that we have a highly educated community in Australia when we compare ourselves with other developed countries. We have not. When it comes to higher education and to advanced technological skills Australia is trailing behind most of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and other advanced countries. Yet we see in the decisions which the Government has recently made on access to education that fewer and fewer people will have the opportunity to develop their skills in a way that would enable us to compete.

Of course, the various decisions of the Government to make study at university difficult, or in some cases impossible, have come about because of three new policies. They are the restriction of access to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme; the decision to introduce a loans scheme which, of course, discriminates very badly against students from poor or even average backgrounds; and the decision to introduce tertiary fees for second or higher degrees. All these decisions, of course, will undermine the standards of our universities and tertiary institutions. All these decisions have already very seriously undermined the morale of the research and teaching staff in all our tertiary institutions.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the very alarming picture regarding participation rates in secondary and tertiary education in this country. The Schools Commission in its most recent report drew attention to the declining retention rates, especially among male students. I preface my remarks on this point by reminding honourable senators that the increase in retention rates to the end of secondary school came about as a result of Schools Commission policies which had evolved through the investment of more public money in education during the period of the Whitlam Government. This was seen as the single most important criterion for the raising of the standards of school education in this country. It is a very alarming fact that so few of our secondary students completed secondary education in the 1950s and 1960s. The proportion of students who stayed to the end of secondary school was far too low.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—The honourable senator asks why. If the honourable senator had been listening to my remarks he would know that access to education in this country is primarily a matter of economics. Before we had significant Federal Government involvement in education at secondary and tertiary levels the only way children could finish secondary education and get access to tertiary education was to have parents who could afford to keep their children at school. A development of policies made secondary education and tertiary education more accessible. That development has been drastically and so tragically reversed by the Government's recent decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The retention rate for male students in the government school sector, which is more significant because of the greater number of students involved, fell from 30 per cent in 1972 to 26 per cent in 1979. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's report on Australia published in 1980 presents very disturbing figures. In relation to full time school enrolments of 15 to 19-year-olds Australia, inauspiciously, ranks fourteenth on an OECD table of 23 nations with only a 45 per cent involvement, in contrast to comparative figures of 74 per cent for the United States of America and 70 per cent for Switzerland. Recently the Tertiary Education Commission referred to a decline in the number of students proceeding direct from school to higher education when measured as a proportion of the relevant age group. The figure decreased from 18 per cent in 1974 to 14.5 per cent in 1980. The report added that this represented a rapid and substantial reversal of the trend towards greater participation of the young in higher education which had been operating strongly for some 20 years. This decline is occurring at a time when demand for higher education is rising steadily in the United Kingdom and the United States of America. As I pointed out, it is making our position compared with other OECD countries even worse. Significantly, the Tertiary Education Commission points to the reduced provision of student financial assistance as having played a significant role in this decline.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you would be a bit more literate we would know something more about literacy. It would be quite different, as you know quite well.

—I find it rather difficult to deal with an interjection which comments on my factual description of a situation where access to education is getting more and more difficult and our position relative to the rest of the world is declining. Senator Lajovic suggests that we have problems with literacy. If we have problems with literacy we will not solve them by keeping students out of schools or universities.

SPEECH.PARA: The supplementary provisions of the two Bills before us this evening can in no way compensate for the recent ideologically inspired attack on learning and scholarships and on the objective of widening access to education. I should point out at this time that the educational objective of widening the group of citizens who have access to education was not only the objective of the Australian Labor Party-certainly that has always been its objective-but also has been the objective of a succession of conservative governments in this country. If we look at the history of education policy in this country after the second world war we find a continuum of development. We saw the supportive policies of Prime Minister Chifley and we saw Prime Minister Menzies, the great conservative leader, take up the question of Australian universities. I am the first to acknowledge the achievement that was made by Prime Minister Menzies during those years. He introduced substantial Federal Government involvement in universities and Commonwealth scholarships and later on introduced some assistance by way of grants to the non-government school sector. None of these things achieved the objective completely, but we witnessed a development towards establishing wider and wider access to education in this country.

Under Prime Minister Gorton we experienced a great boost for colleges of advanced education. A number of colleges were founded with a new and, I think, quite relevant charter of providing vocationally oriented education at a tertiary education level. Then of course under Prime Minister Whitlam we saw the abolition of tertiary fees and the establishment and development of the Australian Schools Commission-the first significant Federal Government involvement in government and non-government schools throughout Australia. If we look forward from Chifley through Menzies, Gorton and Whitlam we see a development of education policies which broadened all the time the access of citizens to different kinds of education and also raised the quality of education available to Australian citizens. All of this was very desirable and, to a large extent, bipartisan. The general public wanted it and major political parties were prepared to agree to development in broad terms. Of course there were some disagreements on particular matters but broadly there was a consensus that education was an important area of Federal Government involvement and justified public expenditure.

Now, of course, we have a drastic and radical departure from this tradition in Australia. We have, for the first time, a moving away from the importance of education as a national government responsibility and objective. We have, for the first time, deliberate policies aimed at restricting access to education institutions at secondary school level and, more significantly, at tertiary level. I will be very interested to hear the response of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick), who represents the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) in this chamber. I hope to hear some explanation as to why, at this crucial stage of Australia's economic and social development, there is a sudden turning away from education as a nationally agreed concensus.

I think a particularly unpleasant aspect of this attack on education is that it has been perpetrated by a person-I am referring to the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser-who obtained his first degree at an English university because his parents were able to afford to send him there. We read in the Press that he is about to be awarded a second degree by an educational institution in the southern part of the United States because his economic policies have toed the line currently fashionable in America.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that to do with it?

—Senator Lajovic's interjection is pertinent to an extent. It is not the most significant aspect we have before us; it is just a particularly unpleasant aspect of the situation with which we are dealing. Let us return to more substantial matters. Let us return, for example, to the decision of the Government to introduce tuition fees for second and higher degrees in tertiary institutions. A number of things can be said. The first is that this represents the breaking of an election promise by the Government. Mr Fife, the current Minister for Education, before the election said:

SPEECH.PARA: There continues to be speculation about Government plans to re-introduce fees for tertiary education. I have given an assurance publicly and I repeat that assurance, that no proposals are being considered by the Government for the possible re-introduction of tertiary fees.
There we have an assertion by the Minister. A few months later we hear of the reintroduction of tertiary fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —What you are saying is not correct.

—Senator Lajovic seems not to understand that students engaged in post-graduate or second degree studies at tertiary institutions are in fact engaged in study at tertiary institutions about which Mr Fife gave an undertaking which has been broken. The fees, of course, will disadvantage students with modest means. Post-graduate awards are awarded on merit and not on need. It is important to point out that only about 15 per cent of post-graduate and second degree students receive the kind of award which obviates the need for the payment of fees. I am pleased to see that Senator Carrick is in the chamber. He was reported over the weekend as saying that most post-graduate students were able to attract post-graduate awards. That is completely wrong. As I have said, the figure is something like 15 per cent. There are simply not nearly enough post-graduate awards to cover all the talented and motivated people who are currently engaged in post-graduate studies.

SPEECH.PARA: Fewer post-graduate students will now enrol; that is quite clear. The majority of post-graduate students will not be able to overcome the problem of having to pay fees. Of course, the withdrawal of students from campuses will not only mean the closing off of options for those particular students but will also be severely disruptive to both the teaching and the research programs currently carried out at Australia's universities. The views of various vice-chancellors have been brought forward in this place and will no doubt be brought forward again, but there is no doubt that those tertiary institutions which have been so carefully built up by a succession of Federal governments of different political complexions ever since the Second World War will now be very severely disrupted in both their teaching and their research programs. Campuses will be unable to plan, courses will disappear because there will not be enough students to take them, staff will lose their jobs because there will be no students to teach and the ability of the universities to maintain and to develop standards will be irrevocably and very severely damaged.

Campuses such as Macquarie University, where I spoke just last week, have a very high proportion of second or higher degree students. This is because Macquarie University was established much later than were the other major universities in New South Wales and has attracted a different kind of student undertaking a different kind of course. I point out that one of the strengths of such a campus as the Macquarie campus is that it has been able to accommodate the needs of many mature age students. We are all very aware that because of the restrictions on access to education-the financial restrictions that prevented people from being able to go to a university-that were very serious before the Second World War and even in the 1950s, the opportunity for many mature age Australians to be able to undertake tertiary studies has meant a very important liberalisation and opening up of new options, personally and professionally. A university such as Macquarie, which has a very high percentage of mature age students-and I might say specifically mature age female students-who have been taking advantage in a most admirable way of those sorts of opportunities, who are proving to be excellent students and who will then go on to join the work force and make a very important contribution to our entire society, will be very severely damaged by the decision to impose fees for those studying for second and further degrees. Of course, once the students are forced to withdraw, once the staff disappears, it will be an enormously difficult, if not impossible task, to rebuild campuses with high standards, with appropriate relevant, modern courses and so on.

The Government seems to think that there is some sort of equity in announcing that although it will restrict access to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme it will introduce a system of loans. Let me remind honourable senators that the very people who most need the loans are the people who will be least able to take them. Students from very poor families or families with moderate means will find it very difficult to burden themselves at that stage of their lives with a heavy loan. Some Government senators say that the students will become lawyers and doctors and will earn a lot of money and they ask why students should not take loans. Of course, if we look at the socio-economic make-up of the kinds of students who go into medical school and law school we find that by and large they come from the most advantaged sectors of society. This is because education at secondary and primary school levels is still not equally available to people in all suburbs and all parts of Australia. The children who can go to the most advantaged schools are the students who get into the most prestigious courses and are able then to enter the most remunerative professions. So we still have a pattern of inequality and the advantaged being advantaged and the disadvantaged being disadvantaged.

Introducing loans into this system will not make things better for the economically disadvantaged; it will make things worse. Young people-perhaps, in the case of a second degree, people who are just starting family responsibilities-will have to take on a loan at a very vulnerable time. Of course, the students who have the security of parents who back them up, saying: 'We will pay the loan if anything happens to you', are the very students who do not need the loan. Not all graduates of universities will become doctors or lawyers. What about the people who go into very low-paid but very important areas of activity? What about the people who work for, say, Aboriginal legal services or voluntary organisations, welfare organisations? They are the sorts of organisations which the Government pretends to support because they use voluntary labour, because they are not bureaucratic and because they often represent a community response rather than a bureaucratic or government response to a social need. Those very sorts of organisations use graduates. The Brotherhood of St Laurence, which is known to honourable senators, is a very good example. Of course such organisations use graduates. They need the skills and the knowledge of graduates but they certainly do not pay $50,000 a year or $100,000 a year, which some of our medical or legal graduates can so easily earn.

If we impose this system of loans we will have two sorts of graduates. We will have the graduates who can undertake a course in law or medicine without worrying about a loan and can then go off and become rich, probably engaging in practices which create a great tax burden for the rest of society; and we will have the people who want to work in areas of need in the community but who will have that option cut off to them because they will have to take a loan and then, of course, they will have to try to find a remunerative job, rather than a satisfying or important job, so that they can repay that loan. So the introduction of the loan scheme will close off options for the less advantaged, will do nothing to equalise the situation as between the advantaged and the disadvantaged and will in no way improve the access of people to tertiary education.

I wish to make some comments about the Government's attack on the Curriculum Development Centre. I point out that the current budget for the Curriculum Development Centre is $2.5m and $1m is set aside for the Education Research and Development Committee. The savings to be made by eliminating these two bodies entirely will be absolutely minimal, so we must look for some reasons other than financial ones for the Government's decision to attack these two bodies. The decision to abolish the CDC takes no account of the major contributions to the Centre by both the States and non-government systems, which contributions for 1980-81 total about $1m. Both of those bodies have conducted and supported important work in research and the promotion of new approaches to education. Some of the research has been directed towards access to education and, of course, some of the results of this research would embarrass the Government. Perhaps that is why these two bodies have come under such severe attack by the Government.

It is very strange to see the CDC under such an attack as this when the Minister, Mr Fife, publicly acknowledged the Centre's contribution to Australia's education at the official opening of its new premises only six weeks ago. Very clearly, this attack, as is the case with many provisions of the Lynch Committee's report, is not a result of carefully considered investigation and planning. It is the result of a last minute decision to wipe out something for what seem to be ideological rather than financial reasons. I am very concerned about the effect on the non-government schools sector of the attack on the Curriculum Development Centre. The Fraser Government likes to pose as a friend of the non-government schools sector. It likes to pose as a government which believes that if parents exercise that sort of choice they ought to be supported and assisted in exercising that choice, as if that had not been exactly the position promoted by the Whitlam Government. But when it comes to longer term assistance to the non-government sector, such as the Curriculum Development Centre was providing, apparently then the non-government sector gets no consideration at all. The non-government sector was heavily involved in the work of the Curriculum Development Centre and I think benefited very much from having a national curriculum development body. So it seems that, whilst the non-government sector is still to receive money, it is not to receive the benefits of national planning by curriculum.

Another question to be asked is this: What sort of pressure is being put on the States to continue the support of the CDC? We have been told by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, that if the States decide to pay half of the costs of the CDC the work of the CDC will continue. Does that mean all of the States, some of the States or the majority of the States? If all of the States do not decide to find the funds to continue the CDC, will the legislation be withdrawn? The Minister in charge of these Bills seems to know the answer to none of these questions, and again it is suggested that the attack is purely ideological and has nothing to do with either fiscal responsibility or administrative efficiency. Least of all does it have anything to do with educational standards. The Government has been heard decrying again and again the standards of some of our schools. Indeed the interjections of Senator Lajovic earlier this evening was a repetition of that kind of decrying of standards. Yet we have a national body which costs very little to maintain and which could bring about the establishment and development of national standards in the core curriculum, and that body is to be dismembered for no good reason at all. It makes no sense.

A similar attack has been made on the Australian Schools Commission. The Government has decided that the direct involvement of the Schools Commission in program administration in the States is to be reduced and that State offices are to be scaled down accordingly. The buildings unit in the central office is to be abolished and the collection of information by the Commission reduced. The contraction of information collection and the dissemination activities of the Commission constitute an obstacle to the debate on education policy and will limit accountability for education expenditure. This Government parades as a government which is a vigilante of the public purse. It indicates that it is concerned to make sure that all public expenditure is accountable and is being spent efficiently. Yet this Government is now demolishing the ability of the Schools Commission to collect data by which we could judge whether the money is being spent efficiently. If the Australian Schools Commission does not know how its grants are being spent or what benefits or gains in terms of education are being achieved, where is that accountability? There is none.

Similarly, the withdrawal of the administrative functions of the Commission at State level will limit and downgrade the service the Commission provides, particularly to the non-government sector. I stress that point because, as I said, this Government is so keen to parade as a friend of the non-government sector, and yet it is dismembering or reducing the ability of those national bodies which have been so helpful to the non-government sector and so supportive in a developmental way.

I should like at this point to make a general comment about the attacks of the Government on the Australian Schools Commission. I believe-this view, of course, is shared by many people within the Parliament and certainly outside the Parliament-the establishment of the Australian Schools Commission by the Whitlam Government was the greatest boost to schools education that this country had every seen. It represented the first serious significant move by the national government into education for all Australians. It was not only a financial development but also an administrative development. It gave a national focus for educational standards. It provided a national focus for people involved in the education communities throughout Australia. It was, I think, welcomed by all people within the education communities. It was certainly welcomed by all of the teachers federations; it was welcomed by the government school sector, the parent organisations, and by the non-government schools sector. Indeed, well may it have been welcomed by the non-government schools because, particularly in the case of parish schools, they were on the verge of absolute breakdown. The burden of maintaining parish schools without significant State aid had become such that most of them were on the verge of closure until the Whitlam Government set up the Schools Commission, established the policy on funding according to need, and then poured all those funds into the parish schools, which enabled them to survive, develop, and in many cases, of course, to flourish.

There were two significant things about the Schools Commission. The first was that it allowed for national involvement in education. It involved all Australian children. The second significant thing was that funding was to be according to need. The Schools Commission was to have the job of establishing the needs in education-country versus city, government versus non-government, primary versus secondary, and so on. For the first time funding was to be rational and according to need. Of course, both of these objectives have been destroyed by the Fraser Government. The Schools Commission has been reduced and reduced until no longer is it able to perform that function of funding all Australian schools according to need and setting national agreed on objectives for Australian education. That, I think, is a great tragedy.

We hear much about the polarisation of the Australian community. We hear much about the unwelcome divisions within the Australian community. We hear many criticisms of our education system and the inability of our education system to meet the needs of modern society. Perhaps there is something in those criticisms, although they are not criticisms which I wish to make personally. But if we are to overcome the polarisation and divisions, the lack of standards, the unevenness of standards, the inequality as between country and city and different States and territories, we must have a national education policy and national education standards. I believe the work of the Curriculum Development Centre and, more particularly, of the Schools Commission would have been absolutely crucial in establishing, maintaining and developing those standards, and that all Australians should have benefited.

One of the most distressing features of forcing programs such as education programs away from the Federal Government back to the States is that we will see dreadful unevenness emerge again and grow a lot worse than previously. Why should it be that a child's chances of a good education depend upon which State he or she happens to live in, or whether he or she happens to live in a country town or in a city? Why should it be that if parents move from State to State-many parents have to do that, especially in these days of high unemployment-their children's education should be totally disrupted, that the children should be totally set back because they go from a State where one standard is important to a State where that standard is not important. I believe that sort of fragmentation and unevenness is not in the interests of our children, is not in the interests of education generally, and is certainly not in the interests of developing a modern competent economy. Yet the effect of the Government's changes will bring about just that sort of fragmentation, disadvantage, unevenness and disruption. I believe all of those things are matters on which the Fraser Government has already been condemned and will continue to be condemned.

In conclusion, I remind the Senate that, whilst the Opposition does not oppose the Bills before the Senate this evening, at the end of the second reading debate we will move to each Bill the fairly wide ranging second reading amendment I have foreshadowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The two Bills which are before the Senate-the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1981 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1981-provide more than $160m supplementary grants and grants for new programs for education projects in Australia. I support both Bills. I am sure that all honourable senators will support the Bills. No honourable senator has expressed opposition to any words in the two Bills that are before the Senate. Indeed, the Opposition has supported the two Bills. It recognises the new programs were election promises designed to assist severely handicapped children, to assist with ethnic language instruction and to overcome in this machinery way, as in the normal fashion, the supplementation that is required to meet cost escalations in relation to projects that this Parliament approved for the years 1979-80 and 1980-81.

SPEECH.PARA: What, then, has been the dispute voiced tonight in the remarks of Senator Ryan, who led for the Opposition in the debate? They have been entirely away from these Bills. They have contained some general, pessimistic, exaggerated prognostications about the impact of the razor gang decisions on the education area. As a Liberal, given the input to that Review of Commonwealth Functions, I believe that we can be happy that there have not been severe cuts in education. We have heard exaggerations about the Schools Commission, which is a good institution and which is performing its job well. Given the refinement to overcome duplication of State funds, it will perform its job better. Given the continuing provision for tertiary education-whether universities or colleges-and increasing funds in the technical and further education area, the Commonwealth continues to provide direct to the States and tertiary institutions a very high level of support for education in Australia.

The Australian Labor Party still labours on the early period of the 1970s when everyone recognised that there was a need to apply more resources to education. But that great expansion has come and since the mid-1970s the urgent and important challenge before all levels of education has been to consolidate those massive increases in funding, to make sure that there is quality in education and that the money is being used appropriately, whether under Commonwealth or State programs. Nevertheless during that time the Schools Commission's targets for standards in secondary schools throughout Australia have been exceeded in all States. The same real levels of funding for universities and colleges and real increases in the TAFE area where there have been real needs have been maintained. I do not think that the Government should in any way apologise for the fact that it places its priority upon achieving quality of outcome for the secondary and tertiary students of Australia.

I believe the red herrings introduced in this debate by the Opposition spokesperson are largely false, alarmist and pessimistic. I refer, for example, to the reflections upon the Curriculum Development Centre. A number of extravagant accusations were made that there was an attack upon curriculum development and that the resources of the CDC would be wasted. The proposal is that the Curriculum Development Centre be retained if the States wish it to be retained and pay half the cost of its programs. After all, the Curriculum Development Centre will serve secondary schools, which are the direct responsibility of the States. As the curricula will be implemented in schools which are the responsibility of State governments, it is appropriate that the States contribute towards funding that body. There will be better co-ordination and better usefulness in the curricula that are developed if there is such a large input. In that context perhaps it is generous that the Commonwealth has agreed, if the States come to the party, to continue to fund the CDC up to 50 per cent of its costs.

I refer to another area mentioned by Senator Ryan, the reintroduction of fees. She called this a breach of an electoral undertaking. At best it is a matter of semantics, but I believe that no such charge can be made against the Minister for Education (Mr Fife). He denied at the time of the last election, under persistent questioning about rumours which will spread by opponents of this Government that fees might be reintroduced, that they were contemplated, that they were discussed by the Minister or that options were being prepared. That statement has never been shown to be false. It has never been shown that the Minister gave an undertaking, in that election context, which is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you were a student what would you have concluded from that?

—That it was a matter for the Government to determine, in the light of the facts in any Budget year, whether some fees would be introduced but that there was no active consideration by the Minister or Cabinet towards the introduction of fees. The same allegations were made by Government opponents regarding the reintroduction of national service in the defence area. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) denied that there was any active pursuing by the Minister or the Government of that option. He was right and that statement was true. It is appropriate for a Minister in an election context to give such undertakings and to make sure that they are true. Every government would maintain that the evidence and the facts should be brought together in any Budget year, in any review year by year of government programs, to allow Ministers to make decisions. So I reject the charge that the introduction of fees is a breach of promise.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to another aspect regarding post-graduate students. Senator Ryan said that this move would destroy research and development in universities and that there would be a falling away of all students who did not have post-graduate awards; that is, were not fully funded, Commonwealth supported students undertaking masters degrees, degrees of doctors of philosophy and other post-graduate study in universities. I believe that that is a gross exaggeration that could never be maintained in any rational debate. It is pessimistic, alarmist and false. For example, the loan scheme to be introduced and which will be available to all tertiary students has not been fully detailed. The announcement on that program will be made in the coming months. What is to stop an enlightened Commonwealth from providing a loan to a post-graduate student that at least equalises the amount of fees that that student may be required to pay in fees for a post-graduate degree?

If a loan is available to a post-graduate student in recurrent terms he will not in any way be disadvantaged in continuing his post-graduate studies and completing those studies. The disadvantage for him personally will come during his employment, when he has an income and will have to repay that loan which was necessary for him to pay for his studies. So priority is being given in the arrangements that have been announced in this Review of Commonwealth Functions to first degree and post-graduate students who are taking their studies with post-graduate awards. Other students taking secondary degrees or post-graduate degrees without an award will, I believe, be able to find the necessary finance from the loans scheme to enable them to take those studies. So I believe that to neglect those options is further to add to the Opposition's record in this matter as having a reaction which is alarmist, false and pessimistic.

I want to highlight four aspects of the two Bills that are before the Senate. I welcome and commend them to all honourable senators. The general provisions of both Bills are machinery matters. Altogether they provide in excess of $160m in supplementation for the purposes of schools and tertiary education assistance in all States and in all programs. In addition, these Bills contain some new proposals which are very significant. One is the additional assistance to non-government schools. I note that in part this is a response to what has been described as a public rush to non-government schools. A recent headline in the Adelaide Advertiser carried exactly that by-line. The article in that newspaper stated:
Private schools in SA are experiencing an application explosion.
Only four or five years ago all the leading schools were actively touting for students.
Now most have waiting lists . . .

The numbers involved in this rush are significant and they are more significant when not only the new places in non-government schools but also the growth in the waiting lists at those schools over recent years are taken into account. So the capital grants that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill provides will enable extensions to schools to be built to cater for students who are increasing in numbers coming to non-government schools.

The general arguments in regard to providing assistance for non-government schools in Australia need be put only briefly. These schools provide equality of opportunity and freedom of choice for Australian families. It is still true to say that in the average situation only about one quarter of the cost of educating a person in a non-government school is met by taxpayers. Taxpayers pay the full cost of educating a child in a government school and on average pay about one-quarter of the cost of educating a child in a non-government school. The assistance in this Bill to allow slightly increased rates for some of the lower levels of schools is again another welcome feature.

The aspect of the program assisting severely handicapped children which particularly interests me and which I commend is that the facilities which will be provided by this extra money will enable education development not only in the institutions where severely handicapped children may live but also in their own homes. I believe this is a response to the call that has been made in all parts of Australia for severely handicapped persons to be able where possible to retain their normal lifestyle and relationships with the family in their homes and when they go to education institutions they are able where possible to go to the normal schools that they would otherwise have attended.

The other new program relates to the assistance to non-profit part time ethnic schools. The money to be provided under the first Bill will enable a $30 per head payment in respect of those who attend language instruction in languages other than English in ethnic schools. The programs must be approved by the responsible Minister. The Bill sets out very carefully the terms of that approval, including the provision that the program be run in a non-profit way and that the language instruction, which may include cultural instruction in conjunction with that instruction, must not, I stress, be wholly or predominantly of a political or religious nature. The Government is seeking by this $30 per head payment in respect of students in ethnic schools to give direct financial assistance not for political and religious controversy in Australia but for language instruction associated with some cultural instruction. I believe this to be of value not only to the younger people of ethnic families in Australia but also to all Australians.

One of the special features of the Bill is that any such approved program of instruction must be open to persons irrespective of their ethnic origin. All Australians must be able to attend for language instruction whether in Italian, Greek, Chinese, Vietnamese or whatever language is being taught in this part time capacity. Language instruction in, say, Greek must be open to a member of an Italian, a Vietnamese family or an entirely English-speaking traditional Australian family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you imagine an Italian child going to Greek lessons after school?

—I agree with Senator Georges that perhaps a person from an Italian family may only rarely be seeking to learn the Greek language after school or on a weekend. Let us encourage such multiculturalism in Australia and while we are so doing let us acknowledge, because I believe this is the direct intent of this program, that we are one Australia, that we have one national language-English-and that we are encouraging in all our citizens and in the children of Australia an awareness of the different personalities of the individuals who live in this country, the different languages of everyone in Australia, the different backgrounds and to respect, to come to learn and to appreciate that in Australia we can be not only English-speaking but also Italian-speaking. I am proud of the fact, Senator Georges, that my three sons will go through primary school learning Italian from grade one. I hope that by the time they get to the age when I first started to learn a foreign language, in my case French, they will be as fluent in Italian as I was after the many struggles in-between football and other activities through my secondary schooling. This is something which we should encourage. I believe this is one of the election promises which is now being implemented and is very much to be commended.

SPEECH.PARA: In expressing my support for these two Bills, I reject the amendments that have been moved and foreshadowed by the Opposition. The Opposition supports the Bills, but I believe the extravagant terms such as 'breach', 'gutting', 'wholly false premise', 'obstacle', 'downgrading' are not only inaccurate charges but also are unnecessarily divisive and not helpful in their pessimistic and alarmist intent of trying to exaggerate the quite minor implications for education in Australia as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

That is not a party political remark. The business of the Senate could be expedited.

The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Opposition's amendments notwithstanding the fact that the third amendment to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1981 is one that we do not totally understand. I suspect that if we did understand it we would not agree with it. It deals with the rationalisation of a number of colleges of advanced education. The Democrats have been arguing for a long time that there are far too many colleges of advanced education and that a number of them could well be rationalised. We have stated time and time again that this is an area in which little bureaucrats can become principals of colleges or see an opportunity to become principals. The bureaucracy then mushrooms and there are more deputy principals, new libraries, new laboratories and a new this and that. Colleges of advanced education have been mushrooming all over the country. I believe the Government is to be commended for pursing that particular line of action. With respect to Senator Ryan, she did not expound on that part of her amendment to such a degree that I can totally understand it.

We agree with the other amendments moved by Senator Ryan on behalf of the Labor Party in relation to the reintroduction of fees. That is a breach of an election undertaking. It is not semantics, as my friend Senator Teague, suggests. It will grossly disadvantage students with limited means and will compromise Australia's research efforts. In fact I think Senator Ryan chose a mild form of words when she said that it will compromise Australia's research effort'. The Democrats believe it will result in a brain drain from Australia. It is unreal to think that the Government, by not funding any person who is undertaking a second degree, will save money and is being just. Where is the justice in the government providing fees for someone undertaking a medical course, which takes seven or eight years at the taxpayers' expense, and someone doing an arts course, which takes three years? Do we say to the person who has taken the arts course: 'You have done your course; that is it'? A person undertaking an arts course will study for only three years, whereas a person undertaking a course such as medicine, science or law will take longer. Does the Government not know that in some areas of advanced technology, such as electronics, a basic degree is almost useless and that a second degree or a post-graduate degree is absolutely vital for any Australian to make a contribution in the highly complex field of technology, electro-processing and so on? We agree with the Labor Party on that point.

We certainly agree that the gutting of the Tertiary Education Allowance Scheme will confirm tertiary education as a preserve of the rich. I am drawing the long bow in my language. It will certainly keep tertiary education the preserve of the middle class and the wealthy class and will certainly militate against those people in worse socio-economic circumstances. Let me tell Senator Teague, who is one of the small 'l' liberals on that side of the House--

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not sound like it at times.

—He is, and I respect that. I would never accuse Senator Davidson, who is attempting to interject, of that. That would be the last thing in the world I would accuse him of being. I would not accuse him of being a small 'l' Liberal or of being a Liberal at all. Senator Davidson can rest easy that I will not be mentioning him in this context. Does Senator Teague know that the present maximum TEAS allowance is $49 a week? That is at least $16 or $17 below the poverty line. We have people such as Senator Teague suggesting that we ask students to exist, to learn, to pass examinations, to obtain a degree and in some cases to bring up a family on an allowance which is below the poverty line. Not content with that, the razor gang has now recommended that the TEAS allowance be reduced further. Any move the Labor Party takes to recify that situation will have the total support of the Australian Democrats. We think it is unthinkable that a student should have to study with an allowance even at the poverty line. Our announced policy is that the TEAS allowance should be 120 per cent of the poverty line. In other words it should be 20 per cent above the poverty line.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats agree with the two amendments moved by Senator Ryan in relation to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1981. Had she consulted us we would have suggested, with respect, that she add the words 'that the Senate views with great concern the shift of funding from the public to the private sector in education'. This matter concerns the Democrats. I have received from the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) an answer dated today to question upon notice No. 278 in relation to the shift of funding from the public to the private sector in schools. I should like to make the point that the kind of information a back bench senator like myself gets from the Government is quite unsatisfactory. I think that the answer I am about to read illustrates the desperate need for the Freedom of Information Bill to be passed. I wanted to know why Dr Ken McKinnon, the former Chairman of the Schools Commission, was not reappointed. I think that is a fair question for a senator to ask. Dr McKinnon was a most distinguished, if outspoken, person in the field of education. I asked whether Dr McKinnon was relieved of his position by the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —You were a little outspoken yourself.
—I am now coming to a stage that when Senator Davidson interjects words fail even me. That is the effect he has on me. I asked the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: Was Dr Ken McKinnon . . . relieved of his position by the Government because of his criticisms of the shift in funding from Government to private schools.

I will read to the Senate the answer I received. It is an insult to my intelligence and it is an insult to the Senate's intelligence. If the public servant who wrote this answer wants to spur on those members of this Parliament who want freedom of information he could do no better than give an answer like this. It stated:
Dr McKinnon was not relieved of his position as Chairman of the Schools Commission. When his period of appointment expired, the Government exercised its prerogative to make a fresh appointment.

What sort of rubbish is that? I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) to convey my remarks to the Minister for Education. I would rather that the Minister for Education or the bureaucrat who wrote that answer treat me with the contempt of not even answering a question than serve up that kind of garbage, which is not worthy of any bureaucrat or public servant who receives taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am brought into this debate because of comments made by way of interjection by Senator Lajovic and certain comments made by Senator Teague. Although, as Senator Teague said, the two Bills before the Senate have the support of the Opposition, it is really a case of the Government giving with one hand and taking away with the other hand. Although this legislation makes money available, the subsequent decisions of the Lynch gang, or razor gang, as it is called, seriously deplete the advantages given by these two Bills. That is the point which is being argued by honourable senators on this side of the chamber. Some remarks were made by way of interjection which did not quite get across to honourable senators the fact that, in spite of the benefits which the Bills transmit, subsequent decisions seriously affect the educational programs of this country to the extent that the Opposition has been moved to foreshadow certain amendments. In spite of what Senator Chipp said, when the opportunity arises and legislation comes before the House it can be amended, as these Bills will be amended, and the debate is broadened. I should have thought that the broadening of the debate by these amendments would have brought other Government senators into the debate because it is necessary not only for the Opposition to put a case but also for the Government to defend itself. The failure of the Government to defend itself seems to indicate that many Government senators do not approve of some of the savage decisions which the Government has announced just recently. Those decisions are savage indeed.
—And from which they are backing away.

—In some ways it is backing away. For instance, there has been some change in the area of fees for second degrees and fees for students studying for a Ph.D. The purpose of the Opposition is to try to drive forward the enormity of what has been decided. There is a failure to recognise the position in which students find themselves these days. My own experience with my family was that at the conclusion of an honours degree, subsequent employment was not available for 12 months. The person concerned was therefore faced with the prospect of doing ordinary work. The time he performed that work would limit his ability for subsequent employment. He was faced then with a decision to go back for a further degree, to engage in study for a Ph.D. Anyone who has any knowledge of what a young student has to do to gain a Ph.D.-the sacrifices, the misery, the poverty, the hard work-can appreciate how enormous that decision can be. Of course, the student, if he is fortunate, will have the advantage of Commonwealth support. But only a few of them have the advantage of Commonwealth support. It amounts to only $80 to $90 a week on which they must survive and, sometimes, raise a family if they are entering that age.
—With extra allowances for that.

—With very small extra allowances, if I might say so, and with all the limitations that can be imposed upon them. Nevertheless, there is hardship and misery. What does the Government decide to do? It decides to make it more difficult for these people to take on the extra degrees, especially for those without Commonwealth support. The reason-I want to emphasise the reason-many of these students study for second degrees is not, as Senator Lajovic said, that they are professional students and that they wish to continue on and on to accumulate degrees. There may be one or two people who are so obsessed, but by and large a student takes the extra degree to enhance his or her qualifications or because there is no opportunity for employment.

SPEECH.PARA: In this society at present there is very little opportunity for employment for those who have the extra qualifications. Let me give an example. Recently, one of my colleagues advertised for a research assistant. He received 60 replies for a job which has a salary level of approximately $14,000-not particularly high for a person with qualifications. Neverthless there were 60 replies. Twenty of those applications were from people holding Ph.Ds. That shows the level of qualifications in the market-place at present. The Government's approach to that is to say: 'Knock it off. There are too many. Let us make it difficult. Let us not allow young people to get these improved qualifications. We have no jobs for them, therefore let us limit the number.'

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not being denied. They can enrol.

—Senator Teague says: 'They are not being denied. They can enrol.' Sure, they can enrol, but the economic limitations which the Government is imposing upon them make it difficult for them to do so. For that reason they hesitate to do so or do not enter that area. But the Government has made a considered judgment that the universities are producing too many qualified people for whom it has no jobs. Instead of taking the step which any reasonable government would take-that is, finding or creating the jobs or creating an economic environment in which the jobs are available-it is turning the clock back. The Government stands condemned for that action. The Government ought to appreciate that the standard of education needs to be maintained at an exceptionally high level at all stages-primary, secondary and tertiary. The funding of schools should be equal and not discriminatory. That is not quite the word I am seeking, but funding ought not to be as it is-an increase in support for the private sector with a reduction in support for the public sector.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot quite understand what Senator Teague said. He said that the trend in South Australia is now for people to apply for entry into private schools. Senator Teague did not explain why that was happening. Is it because the funding of private schools now is at such a level that it can give better education and education to a higher level? Is it because the state schools have been so deprived that the level of education at state schools is limited? Is that the reason? What is the reason? Senator Teague did not properly explain. All I can say is that the method of funding schools in Australia has placed too much emphasis on the private schools and far to little emphasis on the public schools.

I am getting too deeply into the subject now. I rose merely to make a couple of comments in support of the amendments and the need of these amendments to emphasise just how the Opposition feels about the recent decisions which have been made. Today during Question Time I sought to ask a question, but it was not my turn. I accept that.I put the question now because it is relevant to the debate before the Senate. It concerns a statement made by Professor Brian Wilson, the Vice-Chancellor of Queensland University. He stated publicly that the limits on the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and the introduction of a student loan scheme would reduce the opportunity for students from low income families to attend tertiary institutions. He stated also that the introduction of fees for second degrees was not in Australia's long term interests since the majority of students taking second degrees are teachers, thus affecting the future education of all young Australians. When one compares that statement from a person who is very much involved in the education of people and who would be considered to be an expert in the area with the decision of the Government not to fund two colleges of advanced education in Queensland, the Mount Gravatt College of Advanced Education and the Kelvin Grove College of Advanced Education--

TALK.START.PARA: —But they will be funded under new arrangements.

—They will be funded under limited arrangements which, in the very short term, will decrease the number of students flowing from those colleges. It seems odd that the honourable senator does not seem to realise that the Government is attacking the problem incorrectly, that the priority of education funding should be maintained. If, as the honourable member has argued-I believe Senator Carrick has argued this from time to time-there has been a reduction in the number of children entering school because the baby boom has now passed, I would have thought that the answer would be not to reduce the number of teachers available, or to restrict their education, not to close colleges or to limit them, but to reduce the numbers in classes.
—That is happening already.

—It is not happening fast enough. It would be quite easy to reduce the average class size throughout Australia from its present level of around 30 to 20. If that were done many of the social problems that we now face could be countered. The smaller the class, the better the teacher, the greater the opportunity to impart the knowledge and enlightenment that young people require. It would at least remove from the classroom that 'front row' which sociologists have shown to be the origin of much delinquency in our society. I repeat, the Government's priorities are wrong. The decisions that it is making are incorrect. If our society is to improve, if our general standards, values and the quality of our life are to be improved, there should be no reduction in funding of education. Rather, the level of education should be maintained. We should encourage the flow of students and graduates from our universities and make certain that once they do graduate employment will be available for them.

SPEECH.PARA: The economic policies of the Fraser Government have been exposed. We trust that the uncertainties which the Prime Minister now faces may lead him to look anew at some of these problems, perhaps to listen to the cautions which are being expressed from time to time and to change the direction that he has taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well to remind the Senate of what the debate is all about. We are debating two Bills, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. It would also be well to remind anyone who might be listening, or who might read Hansard, that within this chamber there is unanimity concerning the whole of the substance of those two Bills. That is very important to understand. Equally, if one had listened to the debate, one would never have suspected that the Bills not only do what States grants Bills do at this time each year-provide supplementary assistance-but also propose substantially new policies and attain new frontiers of education-in other words, that they represent an expansion in policies. There is a famous Japanese play called Rashomon which depicts how one can look at given circumstances and see in them totally different situations. I have not seen a better example of the scenario of Rashomon than I have seen tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind the Senate of the content of the Bills. I remind honourable senators that the State Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, apart from adjusting cost supplementation, does a number of things. For example, it compresses into three the existing six subsidy levels which apply to all non-government schools. Moreover, it provides an additional $25m for new places in non-government schools. That is a policy matter. It brings in an ethnic schools program and it provides an additional $2m per annum for severely handicapped children, commencing in 1981. One would have thought that the Senate was debating Bills that were pulling down education; that next one would be hearing about a proposed reduction in funding.

In 1981 all government schools programs will be maintained at the same real level as applied in 1980; this, despite a decline in numbers enrolled. Thus, there will be a real increase in per capita expenditure upon each student. Over the last three years there has been a 4.3 per cent to 4.5 per cent falling off in the government school population. That has not been taken into account. Also not taken into account is the fact that recurrent grants have been maintained in real terms. To hear honourable senators opposite one would have thought that the scythe had been put through education. No honourable senator opposite mentioned the arbiter, the Schools Commission. As the world knows, that Commission-which used to be the bible of the Australian Labor Party-set up a series of targets, including the Karmel targets and said that by certain years primary schools should reach particular Karmel goals, and secondary schools should reach them several years later. Who could believe, upon hearing this evening about the Government's supposedly having cut funds, that the Karmel goals, the Schools Commission goals, had been achieved throughout Australia several years ahead of time? That represents an extraordinary situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody believes this rubbish any more. It is nonsense and you know it is.
—The honourable senator says that nobody believes this rubbish any more. The fact is that this is what the Schools Commission has said. These are the targets--
—They were not the targets at all.

—I thought that the members of the Labor Party in this place were complaining about interjections as being disorderly. It seems that the physicians should cure themselves. Again, the discussion tonight would give the impression that diminished funding had brought about a reduction in the numbers involved in tertiary education, but what has happened? In the last year, enrolments in tertiary education have gone up by one per cent, even though the population is aging.
—Not across the board, not at every university, not in every tertiary institution.

—A moment ago Labor Party supporters were saying that they did not like interjections. Perhaps they like them only when arguments are not coming back at them. Technical and further education enrolments have increased by 3 1/2 per cent or more. I refer honourable senators opposite to the transition from school to work programs, to the increase in migrant education programs, the special education program, the handicapped education program and the Education Program for Unemployed Youth. What of all the other programs that have accrued? Then we are told that there is something wrong with the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. I propose to remind honourable senators of the track record in regard to TEAS. We are told that the amount paid ought to be equal to that required to sustain living standards. The Whitlam Government, of which Senator Georges was a member, set up the Williams Committee. That Committee brought down a report-which the Whitlam Government accepted-stating that TEAS was not meant to be a sustenance allowance at all; it was to represent a supplement for the student. The Whitlam Government accepted that principle. In fact, in the last 18 months of its regime, it did not increase the TEAS allowance at all. That allowance declined severely in terms of purchasing power. We are confronted now by the sudden-found argument that we ought to be doing more. In fact, we have brought down Bills which have created new frontiers.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor Party supporters have offered criticism of the Government's policies concerning non-government schools but, year after year, the Schools Commission has reported that the average non-government school has a resources level that is significantly below that of government schools. If there is to be equality, instead of the average in the non-government school being some 70 per cent of the standard attained by government schools, should not members of the Opposition welcome this Government's lifting of the standard in the non-government schools? Always there is the pretense that non-government schools are rich and that government schools are poor. The Karmel targets and the Schools Commission targets showed the reverse, that in fact 90 per cent of non-government schools were in level 6, the class of most disadvantaged. So one by one the dollies fell in the debate tonight.

In summary, there is, I understand, unanimity about these two Bills and about what they seek to achieve. The other matters that have been raised will all have their chance of being discussed when the supplementary measures are brought before the Senate. The fact is that great progress has been made in education in Australia over recent years, and much more is to be made. Senator Georges referred to teachers colleges and to teachers. In the six years from 1972 to 1978 the increase in the number of teachers in Australia was over 30 per cent, although the school population increased by less than 6 per cent. There was an enormous upsurge and expansion in the number of teachers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Through bad planning, of course.

—Indeed, the planning for the intake was done mostly in 1973-75. I acknowledge the planning of those years, but the fact is that there was an enormous expansion. Now with stagnation and a decline in the number of students, naturally we will have problems with the number of teacher training colleges. So there is to be rationalisation. Over recent years the story of education expansion has been a very good one. The Government rejects the amendment and commends the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Amendment (by Senator Ryan) negatived:

At the end of the motion, add ', but the Senate condemns the ill-considered and grossly inequitable changes to the funding, organisation and financing of students in tertiary education as announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions, in that:
(1) the re-introduction of fees is not only a breach of an election undertaking but will grossly disadvantage students with limited means and will compromise Australia's research effort;

(3) the heavy handed threat in the review to 30 colleges of advanced education is based on the wholly false premise that the consolidation of single purpose colleges will result in cost savings in spite of the Tertiary Education Commission's advice to the contrary'.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
