SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My opportunity to speak on the first reading of this Bill was deferred for a couple of weeks and in that time one matter additional to the two other points I intend to raise has blown up. I refer to the disclosure, or announcement, today that the Queensland Government has secured an extra $16m or $17m by means of bluster and bravado after the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said that not another cent would be granted. I have two observations to make about that fact. The first is that it has obviously tarnished Mr Fraser's carefully cultivated macho image. Indeed it has ignominiously collapsed. As always, the Prime Minister, when confronted by Mr Bjelke-Petersen, caved in. The second is that the Premier of Western Australia has been shown to be a paper tiger-he cannot frighten even Mr Fraser. Whilst Western Australian Liberals have done a great deal of local grandstanding, the Prime Minister knows that they will toe the toady line when called upon to do so, whereas Senator Bonner and Senator Martin have shown from time to time that they are rather different.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise two other matters. The first is to lodge a protest about the way in which the Government conducted the business of the Estimates committees and failed to inform the Opposition. Although not a member of the Estimates committees which were scheduled to meet on 27 April, I had a particular interest in several of the issues before those committees. I was told by the Opposition Whip on Friday 24 April-that was the weekend of the air strike, in case it has been forgotten-that if the hostesses strike was still on the Estimates committees would not be sitting on the Monday, as scheduled. That information was confirmed at around 4.30 on the Friday afternoon by the Government with the Opposition Whip and passed on to me. The Whip's secretary did not know until Monday morning that, in fact, the Government had called on the Estimates committees to meet.

There were a number of questions which I wanted to put to those committees but which I was not able to put as I was stranded in Perth. Nor, of course, because of the airline strike, was I able to post those questions to those members of the Australian Labor Party who were able to attend committee meetings. That is in conformity with the way in which the Government has conducted the business of this chamber throughout most of this session and the situation is steadily getting worse. We see anything up to six changes in one day in the order of business listed on the Notice Paper. The Government cannot plan its activities half an hour ahead. Given that it cannot run the business of Parliament House, it is no wonder that it cannot run the country satisfactorily.

The second issue which I have been waiting a couple of weeks to raise is an issue which is again in the news following the Rundle partners scandal and particularly the huge 20 February turnover in which nearly half a million shares on the Sydney Stock Exchange alone changed hands following the visit of the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, to the Rundle site on 18 February. That is, of course, the issue of insider trading. The extraordinarily high number of shares which changed hands following that visit naturally begs the question: Is there some connection between the visit and the subsequent heavy trading on the Stock Exchange? That the Ministers of this Government, especially Senator Carrick and the Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, who waxed lyrical about Australia having sufficient oil locked up in shale to last 12,000 years, were responsible for talking up the Rundle shares in the first place is a matter of public record and is beyond dispute.

There is no proof that any Ministers actually traded in shares or unloaded them on 20 February. However, we know that several prominent Liberals, including at least one Minister, hold or have traded in Rundle shares. These prominent Liberals include the Liberals Party's public relations manager, Mr Robert Baudino; his wife; Senator and various other MacGibbons; Judith Thomson, wife of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson); and, according to an admission wrung from the Prime Minister last Thursday week, another Minister in a direct capacity. One can only speculate on whether that Minister is one of the two present and one previous Ministers who have been reported to some journalists to have been trading heavily in Rundle, naturally through nominee companies. The Prime Minister certainly is not eager to name that Minister or Ministers to which he referred last Thursday week. A year ago he dodged two questions from Senator Wriedt on this matter. The Prime Minister and Senator Carrick dodged many more questions last month and at the beginning of this month.

The Prime Minister's standard reply is that all Ministers are abiding by the Bowen guidelines. The catch is that we do not know what those guidelines are. He asserts that all Ministers abide by these undefined guidelines. When any Minister is shown to be in dubious pecuniary interests position the Prime Minister asserts that that position is within the guidelines, which are still not defined. This is a sort of benign or inverted catch-22 situation in which nobody can be caught. Nobody can be caught outside the guidelines because of their potential, infinite flexibility. The operation is expedited by disclosing nothing voluntarily to the public.

The most notorious insider trading scandal in history was probably that concerning the Poseidon company in 1969 and 1970. Not all of the Poseidon stories have been told. One of these stories concerns one Esther Grace Stevens who worked in the office of Burrill and Jones, who were at the time consulting geologists to the Poseidon company. Esther Stevens bought 300 Poseidon shares between 15 and 18 September 1969. At that time the company was drilling at Windarra. Sometime between 26 and 29 September a Geomin laboratory employee stationed in Kalgoorlie supplied to Mr Burrill the result of the first Windarra nickel assay. At 30 September Esther Stevens, who worked in the office of Burrill and Jones, bought 400 shares, which was fortuitous because the next day the public found out about the assay via a statement to the Adelaide Stock Exchange and the share prices rocketed. That information regarding those dates comes from page 16 and other places in the 1974 report of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange, commonly known as the Rae report.

The 700 shares owned by Esther Stevens would, if they had been purchased at the daily price quoted, have cost $2,495.80 or, in round figures, $2,500. Between 6 December 1969 and 16 January 1970 Esther Stevens sold 570 of those 700 shares. For those shares-again if she sold at the quoted daily price-she received $44,510 or, in round figures, $44,500, a profit of $42,000. She still had 130 shares. Subsequently, without the benefit of the inside knowledge she gained as an employee of Burrill and Jones, her speculation was not so profitable. At this stage I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the purchase and sale of Poseidon shares by Esther Grace Stevens with share certificate numbers and the quoted daily price. The quoted daily price has been obtained from Australian Financial Review reports. The share certificate numbers and other material have been obtained from the Poseidon share register.

TALK.START.PARA: —One point to be made regarding that table, in case somebody picks it up and sees more to it than there probably is, is that one of the dates-6 December-was, in fact, a Saturday, which seems to be anomalous. At that time given the heavy volume of share trading, I guess it is quite possible, that some transactions may have been actually processed on a Saturday. SPEECH.PARA: At the time of this trading Esther Stevens was engaged to one Noel Browne, who has since become Noel Crichton-Browne, a senator elect from Western Australia. Esther is now Mrs Crichton-Browne. It is common knowledge in the north-west that Noel Browne too made good use of the inside information provided by Esther and possibly by others. Unfortunately, his trading is not recorded in the Poseidon register in his own name. Like the Ministers alleged to have been trading in the Rundle twins he preferred to remain anonymous-very wisely too, considering he was a mining registrar at the time. The senator elect is described by some fellow West Australian Liberal members of parliament as 'the crook' or 'that crook Crichton-Browne'. However, he is well qualified to join the Fraser team and uphold the ethical standards established by the Prime Minister, his loan bludging relatives who broke the law of Victoria to get a 4 per cent loan, the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair)--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Standing Orders of the Senate do not give protection to the citizens of Australia, and that is a matter which at times we might regret. I suppose that this is one of them. But when references are made to the Prime Minister he is protected under the Standing Orders as a member of the other place. I simply ask the honourable senator, through you, Mr President, to observe the Standing Orders in his speech.
—Yes. That is so, Senator Chaney.

—Mr President, on the same point of order, I would just like to remind you that during the term of office of the Whitlam Government, the then Prime Minister was often referred to by the present Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick, as being corrupt, deceitful and dishonest. That was permitted to be included in the Hansard record. That precedent has been set. I have here a whole pile of extracts of Hansard if you would like me to quote them. There is page after page of members of the then Opposition using such words. I think it ill becomes Senator Chaney now to try to stop a member on this side of the chamber from accusing another Prime Minister in the same terms as members of Senator Chaney's own party used continually between 1972 and 1975, and which are all recorded in Hansard.
—Mr President, speaking to the point of order, insofar as it is necessary, reference has been made to the period of the Labor Government--
—I thought Senator Chaney had already spoken on this point of order.
—There is no Standing Order which prevents a member from speaking twice.
—Is there not, on a debate? That is surprising.

—It is not a debate, as the Opposition Whip would know. Mr President, the fact is that reference has been made to examples from the previous Government at a time when Senator Justin O'Byrne was the President of the Senate. It may well be that the references made by the honourable senator relate to a substantive motion which had been moved. The Standing Orders are, of course, quite different in their application in that situation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been talking tonight about the functions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee. I would like to talk about some of the functions of government in the opportunity provided by the first reading of this money Bill, first of all in a general way and then in a more particular way. The review committee did a good job insofar as it looked at what the functions of government should be and what resources we should devote to it. But what the committee did was really only phase one. There are two parts to any review of this nature. The first is the actual functions performed by governments and the second is how efficiently those functions are performed-whether we are getting value for every dollar we spend or whether we are spending a dollar and getting only 40c worth. These are two different considerations but both must be weighed if we are to get the cost of government down, which certainly is the aim of everyone on this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The review committee looked at the end points of government actions and looked at functions as ends in themselves. That is a self-limiting exercise because one very soon runs out of things that can be cut out and thrown away. There is a need to go back to basics, to go back and review what the duties of a Federal government should be. Those duties, of course, are quite different in many ways from those of a State government. When the duties of a Federal government have been defined, then we can move to the structure of that government, the ministry, and achieve efficiency in that way. As far as I am aware, there has never been a review of this nature performed in the Federal Parliament. Since Federation, the four basic duties of a Federal government, namely, the offices of treasury, defence, foreign affairs and the Attorney-General, have had functions grafted on to them to accommodate the pressing needs of the time and the demands at a national level or, on some occasions, to accommodate the needs of personalities either in the form of a Prime Minister or for political reasons within the government of the day.

I took the time to write out the present departments of this Government without including the names of the Ministers. To say the least, the result looks very strange. If we look at all those departments and think about them divorced from the personalities, the Ministers involved in managing them, it really is quite an odd list. Looked at in that way, I am not sure that we can argue persuasively that that is the very best way to run Australia. That is an important point because good organisation does not necessarily give good management, but poor organisation makes good management difficult or even impossible in many cases. If we look at the ministries apart from the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate who, I think should be a Minister without portfolio, clearly a case can be made out for the combination of some ministries, the expansion of others, the elimination of some and the creation of some new departments.

One example of combination that is quite glaring is all the finance or money related ministries. I believe they should be combined in some way so that the policies can be co-ordinated. Quite clearly, the offices of the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Finance, the Department of Trade and Resources, the Department of Industry and Commerce and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs all have something in common. I am not saying that there should be only one Minister: Far from it. I think there should be a number of Ministers in the department and really, the number of Ministers is not of any concern to me. Nor am I saying that the one main department should necessarily be split into the sub-divisions which the present departments represent. We obviously would need some divisions in this. But just as we got at the Department of Defence and combined it with four other departments-the Departments of Army, Navy, Air and Supply-to make one Department of Defence, I think the same argument can be extended to Treasury, though taking care not to repeat some of the organisational mistakes which are now manifest in the Department of Defence. That is an experience we can learn from.

That leads me to the case for expansion in the Department of Defence. Quite clearly, the load placed on one Minister in that area is impossible. Five departments have been combined into one. I think it can be argued that we need at least one Minister for the armed services, one for supply and maybe even more.

Dealing with departments that could be eliminated, the obvious choice is the Department of the Capital Territory. We need a Minister for the Capital Territory as much as we need a Minister for the city of Ipswich in Queensland. To have a Minister for the Capital Territory is just a nonsense. All of the State functions that are performed by the Federal Government, such as health and education, do not deserve departments of their own.

While I am on that theme of federal relations, I say that quite clearly the results of the events of last week emphasise the need for creating a department which is responsbile for the management of federal affairs. It is surprising that, as Australia is a federation, that has not been done in a formal way previously. Once there is some agreement on the duties of the Federal Government and related structure, the next step is to go to the people involved in the Public Service-the heads of departments. Most heads of departments are capable people but some of them fall short of the high standards that are required in these positions. It is important to fill these departmental positions with people who have the abilities that are required for the job. When we get people with the abilities at the top we can move down and get the efficiency in the department that we require to give us cuts in the numbers and in costs.

I personally deplore staff ceilings and staff cuts of an arbitrary nature. We lose only the tea ladies and the gardeners when we go about it in that way. We do not get rid of the fundamental structure which has caused the proliferation of numbers. To make arbitrary cuts is bad politics because it just alienates the Public Service against the government of the day. Public servants take the opportunity with the public to attack the Government and to blame it for all the shortcomings. Such cuts are also illogical becaue they take no account of priorities and do not reward efficiency. Reduction in numbers and improvement in operations are achieved by working from the top down, not from the bottom up. I think implicit in this principle is the need to review terms and conditions and promotional criteria in the Public Service and the pyramidal structure of departments. I do not propose to develop that theme tonight because I wish to leave time for Senator Hamer to speak if possible.

I wish to move from a general discussion of the operations of the Government to a discussion of one departmental organisation in particular. One Department seems to have had more than its share of organisational problems in recent years. I refer to the Department of Transport and particularly to its aviation activities. There are many reasons for the problems that have arisen in this area but fundamentally they have come about because the Department has the wrong structure. All we have done is to prove that we cannot combine aviation with surface transport. I recognise the fact that there is a big difference between land and sea, but there is a very much bigger difference between air operations and surface operations. One area is two dimensional and the other is three dimensional. It is rather trite to put it in those terms, but there is a very real difference in attitude and in capacity required to operate in those two fields.

Australia learned how to operate efficient air services over many years. I think we are not living off the fat of that experience. It was a very expensive learning process in terms of both lives and money. We learned under the concept of a single dedicated regulatory service-the Department of Civil Aviation. That Department was disrupted when we acquired the multimodal concept which is really the product of a collectivist philosophy and a collectivist government that was in office at the time. The belief of that government was quite simplistically that all transport is transport and all we need are good administrators to run it.

I should explain that I have some interest in this matter. I have been interested in aviation for many years. I have been flying for a long while and I have owned my own aircraft. I have been very closely involved with the Department. I have a fair insight into the way in which it has operated over a matter of decades. My concerns are with some of the problems that I see connected with the aviation section of the Department of Transport today. I am concerned about morale, the capacity and the capability of the Department, industrial relations-the way in which negotiations are handled with internal airlines and international airliness and the poor state of relations between the Department of Transport and the various sectors of aviation industry. I am very concerned at the slow erosion that is occurring in the safety standards in aviation in this country.

Let us look at morale first of all. People joined the Department of Civil Aviation because they were interested in aviation-not only in flying but also in all of the things that go with it. They joined because that was what they wanted to do in life. When the Department of Transport was formed most of the skilled people came from the old DCA. They were transferred to other transport functions. We had cases of people with aviation backgrounds being sent to be directors of lighthouses or something like that. There is a story, probably apocryphal, of a regional director of civil aviation in one of the States who went on holidays. He was replaced by somebody in the Public Service who had an equivalent rating, who received the same salary and all the rest, but who used to be involved with railways or ships or something of that nature. So no decisions that were normally taken by a regional director could be taken during the period when the replacement filled the post.

All these things together with the shift to Canberra, where the industry has been quite divorced from the Department, have added up to a degraduation in morale. People have lost their esprit de corps. They feel that they do not have an identity, that there is no purpose in what they are doing.

I think the most visible sign of problems within the Department is in the area of industrial relations. Formerly the links were so intimate that the Department of Civil Aviation knew in advance what industrial problems were coming and these problems were intercepted and corrected in time. We did not have the business of strikes by controllers, hostesses or pilots that have so plagued the operations of the airlines in the last five years. There is a very real cost to the community in the lack of that contact. The relations within the airlines are a classical case of what I am talking about. Inquiries are being conducted incessantly into matters related to the airline industry because not many people in the Department of Transport now know what civil aviation is all about. Our relations with the Association of South East Asian Nations have caused us considerable trouble in the international area. That comes largely from the advice that has been received from the Department of Transport. That is to say nothing of the troubles we have had with the Australian population with regard to air fares, both internal and overseas.

The Department also has very poor relations now with most of the sectors of the industry. There was always a competitive atmosphere in relationships with the Department of Civil Aviation inevitably because we had operators mixing with regulators. Quite clearly, the atmosphere in the past was very much better than the one that exists today. There was a basis of mutal respect on both sides for the people in the business.

Erosion of safety standards is a rather intangible matter. Under the separate Department we had the best safety standards in the world. I cannot point yet to any increased accident rate but one senses that things are not all that they might be. There is a lack of experienced people and morale is poor. These things do not bode well for the future. To ensure safety we need careful, analytical thought and discussion, experience, adequate training, discipline, good organisation and a high morale. We have had an erosion on economic grounds of the margins that once existed in the industry. There are now enormous pressures on all aviation operators to cut costs to the bare minimum. This is evidence in graduated power takeoffs, maximisation of seats in aircraft and many other things. They are not significant in themselves but cumulatively they gradually erode the margins of safety that we have built in over the years. In addition to this there is the effect of strikes, the refuellers strikes for example. More and more aircraft are flying when these strikes are on-flying at maximum all-up weight, carrying fuel so that they do not have to fuel at airports where fuel is not available. All of these things add up to an insurance of safety rather than an assurance of safety.

I do not wish my remarks to be taken out of perspective on this matter. I do not wish to be alarmist in any way at all. But it is a matter that needs some very careful attention and some very careful thought.

The most recent activity in which the Department of Transport has been involved has been the General Aviation Study which was tabled in this Parliament a few weeks ago. I hope that at a later date we will have the opportunity of debating that subject at much greater length. I would like to make one point, and go into a little detail about that study. First of all, I should define a few statistics about the general aviation industry. There are 5,865 aircraft or 97.8 per cent of aircraft on the register which fall into this category. The hours flown annually by this section are 1.6 million or 82 per cent of all hours flown in Australia. They carry 133,000 tonnes of freight annually, or 50 per cent of all the freight carried, which is a greater fraction then freight carried by the major airlines. They carry two million passengers annually or 16 per cent of the passenger traffic in this country. The number of aircraft in this category has doubled in 10 years, the hours flown are up 55 per cent and the capital involved in the aircraft probably exceeds $550m.

In this sector the problem of cost recovery is very acute. Basically, the cost recovery doctrine says that all the costs involved will be paid by the user of that sector. In aggregate that means that everyone involved in aviation should pay all the costs of providing the regulatory functions and services of the Department. That rather denies the commonsense point of view that the community benefits by having an aviation industry in this country-from the point of view of defence, from the employment benefit that it brings, the communications and the social cohesion, and above all the tourist trade, particularly the international tourist trade which we are trying so hard to develop. It is not exaggerating to say that someone who never flies as a passenger benefits in living in this community from the services that the aviation industry provides. But when the costs are fully attributed and broken up to various sectors within the industry some problems come to light. They come to light more acutely with the general aviation sector than anywhere else. There is a case to be made that there is taxation without adequate representation. The Department of Transport does impose certain standards of equipment on the general aviation sector that it does not need, that it does not want, but it really does not have much say in the whole business. It is simply told to pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are really needed only because of the larger aircraft flying, are they not?

—That is right, yes, and there are under 200 of the larger aircraft in the country. If the cost could be allocated correctly, no one in the general aviation sector would have any quibble at all. But when figures are bandied around in public that the general aviation sector pays only 12.6 per cent of the cost attributed to it, people in the industry get very concerned. When they are told that that 12.6 per cent will be raised to 34 per cent, in the words of the report 'as rapidly as possible, dependent upon the degree of suppression that can be tolerated' people get very concerned. As Senator Missen said, the operators in this great sector, which comprises over 5,000 aircraft, of which 3,323 are in the private sector-the great majority of aircraft on the Australian register-want only grass airfields. They do not want sealed runways, they do not want elaborate air traffic control procedures. Most of them operate on their own in visual flight rule conditions. I quote from page 60 of the report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Most GA flights in Australia are carried out outside controlled airspace under Visual Flight Rules (VFR) procedures which provide 'see and be seen' conditions.

The demands made by VFR operations are very limited. The do not require elaborate navigational aids, they do not require the things that the airliners require. In fact, about the only thing that is ever used by general aviation aircraft is the automatic direction finders, ADFs, and most general aviation pilots work off the commercial broadcasting stations, because they have a greater range than the non-directional beacons, NDBs, operated by the Department. I quote from page 169 of the report on this matter. The Department takes the numbers of aircraft and relates those to movements. In making its cost attribution, the report states:
The major factor used in the apportionment of airway and operations direct costs was aircraft movements.
Again on page 162, the report states:
. . . the number of movements by aircraft in each of the sectors is often used as a guide for cost allocation . . .

That is the fallacy on which the whole document founders. What is required is for the Department to recognise that there is a very great difference between most general aviation operations and the commuter airlines which are included in the General Aviation Study, and which are essentially public transport operators, and very close to being in the RPT category, and therefore they should be classified in the airline section of the report and taken out of the general aviation section.

I am very sympathetic to the needs of the commuter airlines. They have a much harder row to hoe than the regular airlines. Their financial problems are very acute, and they need support from the Government in many ways. But it is quite wrong to allocate the cost of the general aviation sector, as this report does specifically at page 165, to the private operators. Basically those are to meet the needs of computer airlines which are mini airlines.

If we look at the table on page 165 of the study, we see an astonishing allocation of costs. At competitive airports, which are basically the international airports in Australia the international airlines are assigned $33.8m, but other general aviation, which is principally the private operator, is assigned $38m. That is just a nonsense. There is no way I can go flying into Sydney or Melbourne on demand any time I like. Against that $38m which is allocated to general aviation, only $9.5m is allocated to computer operations. If we look at regional airports, we see that the disparity is $1.8m for computer operations against $11.1m for general aviation. In commuter airports, which are specifically named after the commuters because they operate into them, we have $1.9m for commuters against $11.5m for private operators. This is nonsense. The commuters have to be taken out of the general aviation sector. If that happens, we will get to a reasonable actuarial basis for assessing funds.

I do not wish to continue much longer. I think there is a real case for looking at the operations of the Department of Transport with a view to going back to having a ministry that is concerned with aviation in this country in the civil field. I would like to see that Department go back to the three essentials that it was once concerned with; that is, air operations, air worthiness and air traffic control.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is to remove an anomaly in the Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Act 1977 which affected the amounts which lawfully could be paid to certain claimants. Honourable senators will recall that the beef industry incentive payments scheme was introduced in 1977 as one of a number of Government measures to assist the then ailing beef industry. It was aimed at assisting the cash flow position of producers and enabling them to maintain desirable standards of cattle husbandry. Producers were eligible for a payment of $10 per head of cattle receiving any one of certain approved husbandry treatments during the 12 months from September 1977. Payments were limited to a maximum of $2,000 per producer. Payments made under the scheme totalled $118m. The assistance provided went a long way in helping beef cattle producers to maintain a satisfactory level of husbandry in difficult financial circumstances.

The anomaly which the Bill sets out to correct concern sets of producers who between them own more than one cattle herd. A typical example is where two individuals each own a herd of their own and as partners also own a third herd. As the Act stands, payment of the maximum $2,000 against a claim by the partnership rendered each of the partners ineligible for any further payment in respect of their individual herds. If, on the other hand, claims were first lodged and paid in respect of the individual herds, each of the claimants could receive $2,000 for a total between them of $4,000. The partnership would then not qualify for any payment. These provisions mean that the amounts which lawfully could be paid to groups of producers with similar herds and ownership arrangements could vary depending only on the order in which claims were lodged and paid.

This anomaly was unforeseen when the Act was introduced and the Government proposes that it should now be corrected. To that end, we propose to amend the Act to enable all these interrelated claims to be assessed in the order which maximises the total of the amounts payable. This will ensure that no claimants suffer a disadvantage because of claims being lodged in one order rather than another. Most claims have already been assessed in this way and consequently the amendment will not require any substantial additional payments to be made.

Initially, the Department of Primary Industry assessed claims made by sole proprietors separately from claims by partnerships. This procedure was found not to accord with the Act and to have resulted in overpayments. Claims were then reassessed and action to recover the overpayments was put in hand. The overpayments totalled $432,000 on 300 claims, some 83 per cent of which have since been recovered.

Honourable senators may recall that these matters attracted comment by the Auditor General in his 1978-79 report to Parliament. Subsequently, they were the subject of an inquiry by the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts. In re-examining related claims received from sole proprietors and partnerships the Department of Primary Industry assessed claims in the order which maximised the collective payments to the set of claimants. This was done without regard to the order in which the individual claims were actually lodged or paid. Subsequent advice from the Attorney-General's Department indicated that this course was only appropriate for claims which were capable of being assessed concurrently. Without amendment to the Act it was inappropriate to include a previously paid claim in the reassessment as if it had not been paid. The requirement to take order of payment into account in assessing related claims is the anomaly which this Bill redresses.

As I have explained, the majority of claims already have been assessed and paid in the manner now proposed. Only a handful of existing claims, which have not been fully paid pending a government decision on the procedures to be applied, remain to be finalised. Such payments are estimated at $50,000. If the Act is not amended as the Government proposes, payments totalling some $700,000 in respect of 542 claims will legally be classed as overpayments. That situation results simply from the fact that the claimants did not lodge their claims in the order which gave the most beneficial result permitted by the Act.

I now turn to the specific provisions of the Bill. Sub-clause 3 (1) inserts a new section 9A in the principal Act. The new section overcomes the anomaly to which I have referred. It provides that where the total of two or more incentive payments would vary depending on the order in which payments are made, then the payments shall be made in the order which maximises the total of these payments. Sub-clause 3 (2) provides for further payments to be made in accordance with the new section 9A against the small number of claims yet to be finalised. Sub-clause 3 (3) provides that no previous lawful payment shall be converted to an overpayment by virtue of operation of the new provision whereby the order of payment of claim is disregarded. This is considered to be a necessary safeguard even though an examination of claims has not disclosed any cases where this would occur.

Clause 2 of the Bill provides that the new section 9A of the principal Act shall be deemed to have come into operation from commencement of the principal Act on 10 November 1977. The other provisions to which I have referred will come into operation on the day on which the amendment Act receives the royal assent. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Commonwealth subsidies to Australia's wealthiest private schools being increased by one-third, while subsidies to the poorest independent schools are being increased by only one-quarter; if so, why.

(2) Are present Commonwealth education funding policies deliberately designed to favour the private school system at the expense of Government schools, or is this merely the unintended effect of these policies.
(3) Was Dr Ken McKinnon, former Chairman of the Schools Commission, relieved of his position by the Government because of his criticisms of the shift in funding from Government to private schools.
(4) Is the funding of Government schools now at a standstill despite inadequacies both in staff numbers and teaching facilities at many schools; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In its 1980 election policy statement the Government re-affirmed its commitment to freedom of choice in school level education. Accordingly, it was announced that recurrent and capital grants for non-government schools would be increased during the life of the present Parliament. In his statement of 11 January 1981, the Minister for Education announced details of the first stage of the Commonwealth Government's undertakings in the area of recurrent funding. The existing six-level subsidy scheme for Commonwealth general recurrent grants will be changed to a three-level system. Over the years 1981-83 the basic rate of subsidy will be increased to 20 per cent of standard government school operating costs at both primary and secondary levels.

Schools presently classified to Levels 4 and 5 will receive a supplementary grant equivalent to 10 per cent of government school costs, giving a total subsidy of 30 per cent for the second level. The schools most in need in terms of resource standards, those presently classified Level 6, will be moved to a 40 per cent subsidy rate.

As a first step in 1981, Level 6 primary and secondary non-government schools will receive per capita grants equivalent to 36 and 35 per cent respectively of government school costs. This will provide an estimated additional $12 for each primary pupil and $40 for each secondary pupil over and above the increases already announced in the context of the 1980-81 Budget. These increases mean that 84 per cent of the increased grants would be directed in 1981 to those schools in most need because of their low resources. The table below sets out details of the implementation of the increased subsidy rates.

(2) Commonwealth assistance to non-government schools recognises the right of the parents of all Australian school children to a basic level of financial support from public sources for their children's education, as well as the right to additional support for children in those non-government schools which have a relatively greater need because of lower resources. The minimum 20 per cent subsidy rate has been a long-standing policy of the present Government. Underlying its programs of assistance to government and non-government schools is a concern to ensure that freedom of choice and equality of opportunity continue to apply to all Australian school children.

The base levels of funds allocated by the Government in 1981 as direct financial assistance for government schools in the States and the Northern Territory, through programs administered by the Schools Commission, is being maintained at the same level in real terms as in 1980.
(3) Dr McKinnon was not relieved of his position as Chairman of the Schools Commission. When his period of appointment expired, the Government exercised its prerogative to make a fresh appointment.

(4) To put the overall funding situation in perspective it should be pointed out that for government schools the role of the Commonwealth is one of 'topping up' the resources provided by State Governments and the Commonwealth contribution to governments school costs is about 12 per cent. Any inadequacies in staffing and facilities at particular schools are primarily a matter for the States' attention since expenditures are made, including expenditures from Commonwealth general purpose grants, in accordance with States' priorities, over which the Commonwealth has no responsibility or control.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do Federal, State and local governments in the United States of America offer financial incentives to buyers of domestic solar water heaters.
(2) Will the Australian Government consider offering financial incentives such as tax rebates to those people wishing to install solar water heaters in their homes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal Government in the United States of America offers financial incentives for the purchase of solar water heaters. Some State and local governments also provide various kinds of incentives.

(2) The development and use of solar energy in Australia is being actively encouraged. As a result of the Prime Minister's statement of 27 June 1979 detailing the Government's energy policy, a provision, exemption Item 153, was introduced into the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act which exempts from Sales tax all solar appliances for all uses and certain classes of goods connected with the use of solar energy, such as pumps, stands, racks and motors used in solar panel water flow and storage systems.
These exemption provisions have provided significant financial incentive to people wishing to install solar water heaters in their homes.

In addition, the Government is seeking to make solar appliances more attractive to the public by funding, through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, research projects aimed at improving their reliability and cost-effectiveness.

The Government has provided added incentive to fuel users through taxation concessions which encourage commercial and industrial users of oil-fired and LPG-fired equipment to convert or replace their equipment with plant utilising non-oil energy sources, such as solar.

Last financial year the solar industry had a turnover estimated at about $20 million and about $30 million in sales is anticipated this financial year. Domestic sales have been growing 50 to 60 per cent a year for six years or more.

These encouraging results provide evidence that the community is becoming aware that the rising price of oil products combined with a high average level of sunshine hours per day in many parts of Australia have combined to make solar water heaters increasingly attractive.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it proposed to disband the repatriation artificial limb and appliances centres and spread the functions of these centres throughout the hospitals; if so, what arrangements will be made for the staff of the centres.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Veterans' Affairs has no plans to disband the Repatriation Artificial Limb and Appliance Centres (RALACs). Long term planning envisages that there will be a degree of decentralisation of the service currently provided, with the establishment of prosthetic and orthotic centres in select locations throughout the community.

Over the past few years, as a direct response to the needs of amputees and requests from amputee organisations or institutions providing for the needs of amputees, Repatriation Artificial Limb and Appliance Sub-centres have been established in Canberra, Newcastle and Townsville. Regular visiting services are also provided to a number of other regional centres.

In each instance the sub-centre has been located in an established health facility where the staff of the sub-centre can participate fully in the clinical management and rehabilitiation of the amputee. These sub-centres are staffed by RALAC staff who have transferred from the major centres which experienced a decreased workload upon the opening of a sub-centre. The sub-centres have proved most successful and it is envisaged that further developments along these lines will occur in the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice on 12 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What ordinances or Acts are there in force in the Australian Capital Territory to control pollution by (a) noise; (b) water contamination and (c) smoke or noxious air.
(2) Who administers these ordinances, and what powers do they have.
(3) How many prosecutions have there been of offenders under each of these ordinances during the last ten years, and how many complaints have there been during the period.
(4) How do these ordinances differ from New South Wales State pollution controls.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by my Department that there is no comprehensive legislation in force in the Australian Capital Territory to control either noise, water or air pollution. The following Australian Capital Territory ordinances and regulations allow for limited control:

(a) Noise-The Animal Nuisance Control Ordinance 1975 covers noise emitted by animals; the Inspection of Machinery Regulations made pursuant to the Machinery Ordinance 1949 sets noise levels above which the use of hearing protection devices is compulsory in the workplace; the Motor Traffic Ordinance 1936 allows for the refusal of registration for a motor vehicle which emits excessive noise and provides that it is an offence to drive a motor vehicle which emits undue noise; and the Police Offences Ordinance 1930 provides an offence of emission of noise which causes undue disturbance. In addition, the Small Claims Ordinance 1974 allows individuals to take action to have noise nuisance emitted by neighbours abated.

(b) Water Contamination-The Police Offences Ordinance 1930 provides for offences against the dumping of dead animals and the diversion of water-courses; the Cotter River Ordinance 1914 seeks to protect the Cotter River catchment; the Public Health (General Sanitation) Regulations made pursuant to the Public Health Ordinance 1928 provide for the protection of the water supply; the Canberra Water Supply (Googong Dam) Act 1974 provides for the protection of that part of the Canberra water supply derived from the Googong Dam; the Canberra Sewerage and Water Supply Regulations made pursuant to the Building and Services Ordinance 1924 provide for an offence for pollution of a stream which is part of the water supply; and the Lakes Ordinance 1976 provides for an offence for pollution of a lake and any stream, creek or river flowing into a lake.

(c) Air Pollution-The Building Ordinance 1972 allows the Building Controller in considering plans and specifications to take into account whether the proposed structure makes adequate provision for the disposal of smoke, gas, fumes, and ash; and the NSW Smoke Abatement Act 1902, in its applicaiton to the ACT, provides that it is an offence for a person to use a furnace which has not been constructed so as to prevent the formation of smoke therein.

(2) All of the legislation referred to in (1) is administered by the Minister for the Capital Territory with the exception of the Police Offences Ordinance which is administered by the Attorney-General and the Public Health Ordinance which is administered by the Minister for Health. Various powers and procedures are available under the legislation which does apply:

(a) Noise-The Registrar of Dogs is given power under the Animal Nuisance Control Ordinance to make an application to the Court for an order which may order that an animal not be kept, that specified works be carried out or in any other manner that the Court thinks fit.
The Chief Inspector of Machinery and Inspectors appointed under the Inspection of Machinery Regulations have the power to enter any premises when machinery is in operation.

The Registrar of Motor Vehicles has power to refuse registration to a vehicle which does not comply with registration standards and the Police have normal powers to prosecute persons who operate a motor vehicle which causes undue noise.
The police have normal powers of prosecution under the Police Offences Ordinance.
(b) Water Contamination-The police have normal powers of prosecution under the Police Offences Ordinance;

The Capital Territory Health Commission, Medical Officer of Health and Inspectors have powers under the Public Health Ordinance and Public Health (General Sanitation) Regulations to prosecute offenders;

The National Capital Development Commission has powers to plan and make provision for the prevention of pollution of water supplied or to be supplied from the Googong Dam under the Canberra Water Supply (Googong Dam) Act;
The Proper Authority appointed for the purposes of the Canberra Sewerage and Water Supply Regulations and the Minister have power to prosecute offenders;
The Minister for the Capital Territory or the police have the power to prosecute offenders under the Lakes Ordinance;
(c) Air Pollution-The Building Controller has power to refuse approval for a structure under the Building Ordinance.
The police or an owner or occupier of premises may bring an action under the NSW Smoke Nuisance Abatement Act.
(3) Statistics have been gathered since April 1976 on the numbers of complaints received relating to noise, water and air pollution. These are:
a. Noise-913
b. Water Pollution-118
c. Air Pollution-145
Statistics are not available on the number of prosecutions for particular offences relating to the various forms of pollution.

(4) It has been recognised for some time that the controls which exist in the Australian Capital Territory are deficient when compared with legislation in operation in New South Wales. An Inter-Departmental Committee on Environmental Quality has developed proposals for three new pieces of legislation to replace, where necessary, the legislation referred to above and to introduce controls which will be similar in effect to those in force in New South Wales. This legislation is currently being prepared and it is the intention that the complete package will be introduced within a year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that in certain parts of Canberra, both wattle and gum trees are suffering a degree of 'die-back'.
(2) Have some of the gum trees on Anzac Parade been removed.
(3) Is the problem with the wattle trees one of old age and if so will the Department of the Capital Territory consider replacing these comparatively young trees with species having a longer life.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Dieback and death of many species of eucalyptus (gum) and acacia (wattle) is common in many parts of the Australian Capital Territory and is a cause for considerable concern. It appears to be part of a large scale phenomenon of dieback reported from many areas in Australia.

In some areas the causes of decline have been identified but in other areas it is difficult to attribute it to any specific factor. Causes identified to date include the effects of insects which attack above and below-ground parts of trees, pathogenic fungi, particularly those which attack fine roots, grazing by native animals such as possums and domestic livestock such as cattle, sheep and horses and changes in the physical and chemical features of the environment following fire, drought, flooding and water-logging of soil, wind and cyclonic storm damage, land clearing, application of fertilisers, road construction and the use of herbicides.

In urban areas eucalypts are more often affected by root damage due to construction work such as trenching and changes of levels. Water stress is more apparent in areas such as bitumen car parks. At the present time many trees in Canberra are suffering from a severe attack of Psyllids causing the foliage to die off. Repeated attacks weaken trees and some may be killed.

(2) A number of Eucalyptus St. Johnii have been replaced along Anzac Parade. In most instances, the deaths can be attributed to severe spiral rooting initiated when the young trees were growing in large tins prior to planting out and aggravated by the poor quality soil in which they are now growing.

(3) Most acacias are short lived due mainly to attack by wood borers. Life expectancy varies between 10-20 years. They develop rapidly to provide a desirable screening effect and are favoured for this purpose. In many situations it is not intended to replace them when they are removed as other slower growing species take effect.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there to be an international netball competition in Australia in June 1981.
(2) Has the Government contributed over twenty thousand dollars to the event; if so, what is the exact amount.
(3) Has the Australian Broadcasting Commission refused to provide television coverage of those events.

(4) Are these events to be held in major venues such as the Horden Pavilion in Sydney and Festival Hall in Melbourne, and do a million people play netball in Australia; if so, does the Government consider that the situation regarding the coverage of the events is acceptable.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An International three-way Test Series will be played in Australia between New Zealand, England and Australia in June 1981.
(2) The Commonwealth Government has contributed $15,000 to the event from the Sports Development Program.

(3) The Australian Broadcasting Commission has advised the Department of Home Affairs and Environment that it has not refused to provide television coverage of the events. It has offered to provide such coverage as is possible within its available resources and is awaiting a response to this offer.

(4) These events are to be held in the Hordern Pavilion, Sydney, Festival Hall, Melbourne and the Commonwealth Games Centre, Chandler, Brisbane. The All Australian Netball Association has approximately 300,000 registered participants. This figure does not include players at school level and it is estimated that the number involved at this level is in excess of 500,000. It would seem that the Australian Broadcasting Commission is doing all that it can to provide coverage of the program. The question of commercial involvement is, of course, a matter for the competition organisers and those networks involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1981 (Hansard, page 81) Senator Davidson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Education, a series of questions, without notice, concerning the Australian Education Council's decision to establish a steering committee with a view to the creation of an Australian Children's Television Foundation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Education Council at its February 1981 meeting did resolve to support the establishment of an Australian Children's Television Foundation. I can confirm that the Council has agreed to the setting up of a steering committee convened by the New South Wales Minister for Education and the Victorian Minister for the Arts with a view to creating the Foundation. The Commonwealth has a representative on the steering committee. All States, except Queensland, have nominated members.

The form the Foundation might take and the extent of its responsibilities will depend on agreement between the Commonwealth and the States, but it could be expected that the objectives of the Foundation would be consistent with the need expressed by the Senate Committee for an independent authority which would stimulate the production of programs available for children.

Until the report of the steering committee is available, I am not able to comment further on the ways in which a contribution by the Commonwealth might be made. This will be a matter for consideration by the Government when firm proposals have been formulated for the consideration of Commonwealth and State Ministers. I expressed the view at the February meeting of Council that no assumptions should be made concerning the Commonwealth's attitude to the appropriate level of funding for the Foundation and to the Commonwealth share.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1981 (Hansard, page 413) Senator Evans asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, two questions, without notice, relating to the appearance of Public Service witnesses before parliamentary committees. He also asked whether I was aware that the Guidelines for Official Witnesses Appearing Before Parliamentary Committees, tabled in the House of Representatives by the Government on 28 September 1978 had not been adopted or debated by the Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to seek out any further information I could give. The Prime Minister has provided the following information:

The guidelines were prepared by the Government to provide guidance for its officials. They were tabled in the Parliament so that the Members of Parliament would be aware of the guidance provided officials appearing before committees, and so that any views expressed on them could be considered. Thus the question of their formal approval by the Parliament does not arise.
The guidelines reflect the principle that while officials should provide all factual information possible, Ministers alone are responsible for Government policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1981 (Hansard, page 415) Senator McIntosh asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. His question concerned the upgrading of Nomad aircraft to enable them to perform photographic/survey work.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

A Request for Proposals (RFP) for photographic/survey aircraft was distributed world-wide in November 1980. While proposals were received from nine companies-based on 14 variants of nine types of aircraft-no proposal was received from the Government Aircraft Factories based on the Nomad aircraft.

You may not be aware that aircraft that can fly long ranges and at high altitudes have considerable advantages over aircraft like the Nomad for the kinds of photographic/survey work now carried out by our Canberra aircraft. It may interest you to know however, that the Army does use the Nomad to assist in the support of photographic/survey work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 March 1981 (Hansard, page 564) Senator Colston asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence in the Senate. His question concerned the appointment of a Defence Force Ombudsman.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As I advised the Senate on 28 February 1980, the Department of Defence proposals dealing with the establishment of a Defence Force Ombudsman had been examined by the Administrative Review Council, and the recommendations of the Council had been accepted.

Proposals for draft legislation for the appointment of a Defence Force Ombudsman within the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman are being prepared, and it is hoped that shortly it will be possible to announce plans for the establishment of a Defence Force Ombudsman.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 April 1981 (Hansard, page 969), Senator Puplick asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question, without notice, concerning the Australian documentary film Frontline.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am advised by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that commercial television stations have indicated that they have not taken up the Australian documentary film Frontline for basically the same reason as that advanced by the Australian Broadcasting Commission, namely, that the price being asked for the television rights is more than the television stations pay for similar material. No doubt further negotiation in what is purely a business transaction, will eventually resolve the matter and enable the Australian public to see this widely acknowledged film.
